card.desc:
The shape of our tree can guide our work: The breadth & depth reflects our knowledge of the customer

- One that is too shallow indicates a potential need to do more customer interviews to discover more opportunities
- One that is too sprawling is a reminder to narrow our focus
- If there aren't many solutions identified for the target opportunity, we can hold an ideation session.
- If we don't have enough assumption tests in flight this can prompt us to ramp up testing

Top down & bottom-up.

Many teams work from the top - identifying a desired outcome, mapping the opportunities, then solutions, then assumption tests. However great teams can also work bottom up: **using assumption tests to evaluate solutions and evolve the opportunity space**. In evaluating the opportunity space, understanding how they might best reach that outcome, and how to measure that outcome  will evolve. 

They interview week over week, continuously revising the tree, even after selecting a target opportunity. They consider multiple solutions to the target opportunity, setting up good compare and contrast decisions. They run assumption tests in parallel across the solution set, so they don't over-commit to less than optimal solutions
card.name: Tending to an Opportunity / Solution tree (the arborist) ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

card.desc:
Both direct, probing questions and open-ended questions can be useful in different situations. A good question to ask yourself is **what's the most likely way I could fail to get the right information in this situation?**

I.e.

- By not discovering a flaw or issue? (direct, probing question)
- By not hearing what people really think about a solution? (open-ended questions)

card.desc:
Try:

**The Vanishing Options Test**

_What if you couldn't do any of the things you're considering, what would you do instead? What if you were forced to invest your money into something else... what would you buy?_

**Multi-tracking ideas** to set-up compare and contrast decisions and improve the quality of our ideas

**Create more balanced ideas by toggling between prevention and promotion mindsets**

**If we get stuck, find someone who has already solved our problem**

- Look inside (for bright spots)
- Outside (for competitors and best practices)
- Into the distance (by laddering up analogies)

Pick off something that will be functional across the front and back ends. Something that can demonstrate progress, momentum and that can be achieved within a few days.

Start at the middle, where the interesting problem is. This will help de-risk.

The thing you pick:

- It should be core
- It should be small
- If there are things that are both core and small, prioritise that which is novel (we haven’t done this before)

Following this will help reduce uncertainty and prove that something can work

card.desc:
###An experimental feature: Hill Charts


A third example shows some grey area. When we built the Hill Charts feature in Basecamp (see Chapter 13), we had no idea if it was going to work out or not. Basecamp was an existing product, and it felt too risky to bet on releasing this experimental feature to customers. 

So we framed the project more like a production mode bet on a new product. We shaped a first version that was just functional enough to use ourselves. We didn’t expect to ship it to customers without doing an additional cycle on it. This was a risk: we bet one cycle, not two. If it didn’t work out, we’d scrap it. If something more important came up, we might not ever schedule the second cycle. But we ended up feeling confident after the first cycle. We shaped a project to round it out, decided to bet another cycle, and then shipped it to customers.
card.name: Shape up for Experimental features (A hybrid approach)
Shape up for Experimental features (A hybrid approach)

When it comes to the betting table, it seems appropriate that the product trio would have multiple bets to table (pitches) across one or multiple opportunities. 

This way, the team making the bets can make a compare and contrast decision, rather than just evaluating one…. With just one, it becomes a meaningless ritual too.

Aim for 3 pitches at each 6/8 week betting process

card.desc:
Could be used in conjunction with approach outlined here: https://trello.com/c/7xNTQXmw

——

This is a roughly 6-page document which describes in narrative form the problem you’re trying to solve, why this will be valuable for your customers and for your business, and your strategy for solving the problem.

This approach will help point out blind spots in your process, it will help you anticipate and resolve questions from stakeholders before making a presentation, etc.

——

The structure is to write the narrative itself in a few pages and then follow this with an FAQ. The idea is to anticipate the different concerns and objections that might come from key executives and stakeholders, take the time to consider and werite up clear answers to these objections, and then review these responses with the people that have these concerns.

When an executive reads the narrative later, they can see that you anticipated the issues and considered the response and they know that you have done your homework.

——-

Use cases:

- Major decisions, and especially to facilitate decision meetings. Get everyone to read the narrative to then be discussed and make an informed decision.
card.name: The Written Narrative as product & communication tool

card.desc:
The PM is not there to dictate solutions to stakeholders, and while the majority of actual collaboration for a product team is happening between the product trio, the PM recognises that each stakeholder is responsible for some key aspect of the business and that they are a key partner in helping to come up with a solution that works.

There are good examples of this i.e. in cases where what we are trying to do has legal implications, so the legal stakeholder is your partner in understanding the constraints and helping to evaluate the suitability of various approaches.
card.name: A good product trio knows to continuously manage stakeholders. Share your work along the way, rather than all at the end

card.desc:
For collaborating on solutions, sitting around a prototype can be a great way to get collaboration in the product trio. 

The designer can consider different approaches to the experience, the engineers can consider the implications of different approaches and potential of enabling tech… PM can consider marketing / sales / privacy / whatever considerations.

In discover, the story map serves the same purpose. The very act of creating and discussing these artefacts facilitate try collaboration.

And keeping these up to date, they can capture the learnings and decisions from discovery work.

card.desc:
Requires 2-3 months of time to ramp up, assuming 2-3 hours per day is being spent on it.

#### Customer & User Knowledge

Beyond visiting customers….


- Your team (engineering & design leads)
- Start with the user research team, if there is one
- Then the customer success / service team
  - Learn who their fav customers are, their least fav, and why
  - Understand more about how customers perceive your product.
  - Learn what they can teach you about your users and customers
- Product Marketing has a valuable perspective on users and also good insights into the broader sales and marketing divisions and who you should talk to in there
- Founders / CEO
  - Which customers they consider the most helpful for you to truly get to know and understand. Not just happy, but unhappy too… you’re after as many perspectives as you can get.
- At this point you’re able to go out and meeting real users and customers.
  - Marty recommends at least 15 customer visits as part of new PM onboarding.

####Data knowledge

User analytics: How users interact with your product
Sales analytics: The sales cycle for your product
Data warehouse analytics: How this data is changing over time

_The idea is to attain competence with each of these tools which means two things:_

- You know how to answer questions with that tool
- You need to understand what the data in the tool is trying to tell you.

####Industry and domain knowledge

Key to industry knowledge is identifying which industry trends are expected to be relevant to the pM’s product.

- The first step is to identify the trends, and there may be some education needed to understand what the trend or technology enables and what the capabilities and limitations may be.
- Also included is competitive analysis. Product marketing is a good place to get started, but the PM will need to have a deeper understanding of the offerings, vision and strategy of each of the major players in the landscape
  - Marty’s approach is to ask the PM to evaluate the top three to give players in the pace and write up a narrative comparing and contrasting the strengths and weaknesses of each player - i.e. highlighting opportunities

#### Business and Company knowledge

An essential difference between competent and incompetent PMs.

- Have the new PM fill out a business model canvas for their product. It is a quick and easy way to help the PM quickly realise the areas they might not understand.

#### Sales & Marketing - Go-to-market

The go-to-market strategy describes how our product makes it into the hands of users and customers. It applies to every product.

I.e. direct sales force, resellers, directly over the web. Etc.

The sales process starts with marketing which itself has many different strategies and techniques. Ultimately there is always some type of funnel starting with people becoming aware you exist, and hopefully through to active customer.

- The new PM needs to understand the entire funnel from awareness, to trials and to onboarding.
- It’s especially important to understand the capabilities and limitations of the sales channel. 

####Finance - Revenue and costs.

- Marty advocates making a friend in finance for this purpose. There are financial related KPIs for every product and you need to understand:
  - What those KPIs are (e.g. lifetime value of the customer
  - What they mean 
  - Where your product stands… e.g. is lifetime value sufficient compared to your CAC (LTV / CAC)

####Privacy and Compliance 

Privacy, security, compliance, ethics. Make a friend in legal who can help the new PM understand legal constraints.

####Biz dev & partnerships

Agreements with tech partners, marketing partners etc, usually come along with constraints about what we can do, it’s important to understand these.
card.name: Acquiring Product Knowledge (An onboarding plan of sorts)

A good product trio knows to continuously manage stakeholders. Share your work along the way, rather than all at the end

card.desc:
We’re often asked for our conclusions - our roadmap, our release plan, our prioritised backlog, and more often than not, teams will oblige.

The challenge with this is that stakeholders will have their own opinions on these artefacts, even though they haven’t done the discovery work that you have. When you go straight to the solution space you’re implicitly framing the conversation to be about your opinion what too build, versus your stakeholders’ opinions.

——

Instead of starting with your conclusions, slow down and show your work,

The OST can be used to share your work - how you charted the path towards your desired outcome. It helps you to set context for how product decisions are made.

####Start at the top of your tree.

Remind stakeholders what your desired outcome is. Ask them if anything has changed since you last agreed to this outcome.

#### Share how you mapped out the Opportunity Space.

Highlight the top-level opportunities and drill into detail only when they ask for it. 

Ask them if you missed anything, consider that they may have knowledge of opportunities that you may have missed and capture their suggestions - you can always vet them in your future customer interviews.

####Share how you assessed and prioritised the opportunity space

Ask them if they would have made a different decision at each decision point….

####Share more context about your target opportunity.

- Help them fully understand the customer need or pain point you intend to address.
- Use the interview snapshots to help your stakeholders empathise with the customers.

^ This is crucial, they need to fully understand the opportunity before you share solutions with them

This is what helps move the conversation away from opinions and preferences.

####Share solutions and ask them if they have any feedback or ideas of their own

- Capture their suggestions
- Share the three solutions you’re intending on moving forward with. Ask them if they would have chosen a different set. Keep open minded, remember solutions are a dime a dozen. Diversity is useful.

#### If started, share your story maps and assumption lists

- Ask them to add to the assumptions list, this is where their different perspective and expertise can help catch out your blind spots.
- Ask them if they would have prioritised the assumptions differently. Make adjustments as needed.

####Share your assumption tests and/or execution plans

——-

###^ Instead of sharing our conclusions, we are instead asking the stakeholders to co-create with us, inviting them to assess our thinking and add their own. We’re improving our process by leveraging their expertise.
card.name: Don’t jump to your conclusions (i.e. the roadmap, solutions etc) Instead, share the journey
Don’t jump to your conclusions (i.e. the roadmap, solutions etc) Instead, share the journey

Don’t bother trying to set everything up, up front (see pages 187-188…) Without doubt you’ll waste time and effort. Trust that you’ll learn as you go and instead of trying to plan everything up front, start small and experiment your way to the best instrumentation.

——

**Instrument your evaluation criteria**

Start by instrumenting what you need to collect your assumption tests (i.e. live prototypes)

Over time, you’ll want to instrument your product such that you are measuring not just impact on your product outcome, but impact on your business outcome. This may take time and may be hard, but it is important.

card.desc:
Not a simple question to answer.

Often, discovery requires you to start delivery - i.e. a coded prototype in production to split traffic & test. And often, measuring the impact of this delivery, results in the need for more discovery.

This is why we say discovery feeds delivery and delivery feeds discovery. They aren’t two distinct phases. You can’t have one without the other.

You want to iteratively invest over time, starting small with assumption tests. However, as your experiments grow, you will need to test with a real audience in a real context, with real data. Testing in your production environment is a natural progression of the discovery work. It’s also where your delivery work begins. If you instrument your delivery wort, discovery will not only feed delivery but delivery will feed discovery

We’ll be learning how to keep discovery & delivery tightly coupled so that you never have to wonder if you are ready for delivery
card.name: Q: When do we send our ideas to delivery?
Q: When do we send our ideas to delivery?
Note: A default assumption to have in the background when testing: That this will have a positive impact on our desired outcome

card.desc:
Page 185-186

The assumption test example showed great results on traffic and starting a journey… but it hasn’t actually proven it was driving the desired outcome.

Sometimes we might like to run the assumption test longer to confidently test the impact on the outcome.

We need to remember to measure not just what we need to evaluate the assumption test, but also what we need to measure impact on our outcome.
card.name: Note: It’s tempting to get caught up in the success of an assumption test. Be sure to tie it back to the outcome you are seeking
Note: It’s tempting to get caught up in the success of an assumption test. Be sure to tie it back to the outcome you are seeking

old.desc: Design them so they are most likely to pass. If they do, you can expand the test to tougher audiences. If you fail the best case scenario, your results will be less ambiguous.

card.desc:
Be sure to define your evaluation criteria up front, i.e.:

- How many search queries will you sample?
- How many need to be related to sports?
- How will you determine "related to sports"

^ this guards against confirmation bias and ensures your team agrees on what the results mean.

card.name: Essential tool for efficient assumption testing: Unmoderated user-testing
Essential tool for efficient assumption testing: Unmoderated user-testing

card.desc:
When testing with small numbers and quickly, there will sometimes be false-positives and false-negatives in our results.

This does present a cost:

- For false-positives, the costs associated with doing an extra assumption test
  - Usually only a few days, provided the testing is kept lean
- For false-negatives, we might design around the failures unnecessarily
  - Note, we shouldn't just throw out an opportunity based on one negative.... we should have multiple tests in play or sequenced to triangulate data.

There _is_ a cost to false positives & negatives, however the cost is not so great that we should be starting with large-scale, quantitative experiments every time. If we did that, we would never release any software. Our tests will simply take too long. The vast majority of the time, you will learn plenty from small-scale tests
card.name: The argument for lean testing

card.desc:
techniques:

- Walking the lines of the story and going through the assumption categories
- Conduct a pre-mortem (predicated on the idea that this _will_ fail and you're looking back after 6 months on what went wrong)
- Exploring potential harm (i.e. black mirror test)

If they are not test-able they are not specific enough
i.e.

- Customers will have time
- Customers will know what to do
- Our engineering team can build something like this.

Instead:

- Customers will take the time to browse all the options on the getting started page
- Customers will know how to select the right option based on their scenario
- Our engineers can identify the right sub-set of options to show, based on the customer's user profile data.

old.desc:
Mapping out each step the user needs to take to get value out of the product or service.

- It forces you to be very specific about how an idea will work and what you expect users to do to get value.

To do:

- Start by assuming the idea already exists (don't story-map what it will take to implement the idea, but simply what end-users will need to do to get value out of it in the real-world)
- Identify the key actors (often there are multiple users / groups required to interact to get value delivered
- Map out the steps each actor must take to get value 
- Sequence the steps horizontally over time

card.desc:
Mapping out each step the user needs to take to get value out of the product or service.

- It forces you to be very specific about how an idea will work and what you expect users to do to get value.

To do:

- Identify the key actors (often there are multiple users / groups required to interact to get value delivered
- Map out the steps each actor must take to get value 
- Sequence the steps horizontally over time

-----

Note:

- Map out the successful path, not all possible paths.
- You will have to make some critical decisions along the way (that's fine!), i.e. search will happen on our platform, not the partner's platform. We are assuming that's possible at this point, that's fine - we have to make assumptions before we can test them!

old.desc:
1. Filter out those that don't actually solve the opportunity
2. Team dot vote to filter down to 3 ideas. The only consideration at this point is 'how well does the idea address the target opportunity'. You don't rule out the hardest or even impossible ideas at this point. That can come later
3. Check everyone is excited about at least one of these ideas.

The goal at this point is to set up a good compare and contrast decision: Which of these ideas best delivers on our target opportunity?

We'll go about answering that question with prototyping and assumption testing.

old.desc: When you get stuck, start with your competition, but then look wider - ask yourself, what other industries have solved similar problems?

card.desc:
When you get stuck, start with your competition, but then look wider - ask yourself, what other industries have solved similar problems?

i.e.:
- how do online shopping websites help people evaluate products
- how do travel aggregators help people evaluate hotels
- how do insurance companies present different policies?

card.desc:
- All prioritisation decisions are two-way doors
- If all opps emerged from customer interviews, there are no wrong decisions

The best way to ward against analysis paralysis is time-boxing your decision. Give yourself an hour or two, or at most, a day or two. Then decide, based on what you know today, and move on.
card.name: Anti-pattern: Delaying a decision until there is more data
Anti-pattern: Delaying a decision until there is more data

card.desc:
**One-way-door**: A decision / opportunity that is hard to reverse

- We should be slow and cautious when going through a one-way door. Be cautious, data driven, deliberate in decision maing.

**Two-way door**: A decision / opportunity investment that is easy to reverse

 - Move fast and not wait for perfect data.

In the case of two-way door opportunities, we'll learn more by making a decision and seeing the consequences of having made that decision, than we will from trying to think our way to the perfect decision.

- Prioritising opportunities are always two-way door decisions. When we make a priority, we're choosing how to spend the next few days or weeks. We're not committing to addressing that opportunity, simply, we are committing to exploring it further with our discovery work.

- It's important to have a structure and approach that supports two way decisions. Research choose that if people view a decision as irreversible, they'll tend to notice only the positive attributes of their chose and the negative attributes of the alternative. If we want to ward off confirmation bias, it's critical we think of our prioritisation decisions as reversible. 

- With continuous discovery we can always course correct as we learn.
card.name: Two way door decisions, data informed vs analysis paralysis
Two way door decisions, data informed vs analysis paralysis

card.desc:
This is a messy, subjective process which is appropriate for an ill-structured problem. The important part is compare and contrast against multiple options rather than trying to accurately quantify anything.

The main thing we want to do is have a healthy debate as a team, consider the different dimensions, think about each set of criteria as a different lens through which to view impact. Use this to fuel the conversation.

If we put a formula or numbers over this, it's tempting to think there is one right answer, and tempting to stop thinking.
card.name: Embrace subjective decision making (don't assign numbers & formula)
Embrace subjective decision making (don't assign numbers & formula)

old.desc:
### Opportunity sizing

**How many customers are impacted and how often?**

- This doesn't need to be precise, instead it's done in a compare & contrast way against the siblings. 
  - We can and should make rough estimates here, you can use behavioural data (i.e. analytics, support tickets, sample surveys, or even interview snapshots
- It's important to distinguish 'how many' from 'how often'. Every customer might be impacted by an opportunity, but this may only arise occasionally.

### Market factors

**How addressing each opportunity might affect our position in the market.**

- i.e. 'table stakes' (the minimum offering that is acceptable in a market - where missing one might torpedo sales)
- i.e. 'strategic differentiators' (which might open up brand new customer segments).
- Consider: how does addressing each opportunity position you against your competitors.
- We also want to consider any external trends (both opps & threats) that might impact what we choose. For example, perhaps there is a trend happening of people consolidating their sub services in an economic depression) - we can consider the impact of that on different opportunities that we're looking at

### Company factors

**Help us evaluate the strategic impact of each opportunity for our company, business group or team**

- Google might choose an opportunity, that Apple would never touch. We need to consider the org context when assessing & prioritising. I.e. values, etc. we want to prioritise opps that support company vision, mission, strategic objectives over ones that don't. We want to re-prioritise those that conflict with company values
- You'll also wanted to consider team strengths & weaknesses. Some companies will be better positioned to tackle some opportunities over others. Some teams may have unique skills that give them an unfair advantage.

### Customer factors

**Help us to evaluate hoe important each opportunity is to our customers**

- If we interviewed and opportunity mapped well, every opportunity on our tree will represent a real need, pain point or desire. However not all are equal.
- We want to consider:
  - How important each opportunity is to our customers _and_
  - How satisfied they are with existing solutions
- **We want to prioritise opportunities in the high importance, low satisfaction quadrant**

--> see Dan Olsen's important / satisfaction matrix

card.desc:
First, assess the top-level opportunities in a compare and contrast decision.

When you've identified the highest priority of these, work down the tree. You can now ignore the other sections of the tree that weren't prioritised at that top-level.

Rinse and repeat all the way through the parent / child structures until you settle on one single, child opportunity to work on and solve.
card.name: Using the tree to aid decision making
Using the tree to aid decision making

card.desc:
The easiest way to distinguish between an opportunity and solution is to ask: **Is there more than one way to address this opportunity?** A solution has just one.

i.e. "I wish I could fast forward through commercials"
card.name: Anti pattern: Solutions in disguise
Note: Being on watch for solutions
Note: Being on watch for solutions
Note: Being on watch for solutions

old.desc:
Opps that represent themes, design guidelines, or even sentiment are not specific enough. 

"I wish this was easy to use" is not good. We can make them more specific and better however: "I wish finding a show to watch was easier"

card.desc:
Opps that represent themes, design guidelines, or even sentiment are not specific enough. 

"I wish this was easy to use" is not good. We can make them more specific and better however: "I wish finding a show to watch was easier", broken down into children opps such as "Entering a movie title using the remote is hard"
card.name: Anti pattern: Opps that aren't specific

card.desc:
Opps that represent themes, design guidelines, or even sentiment are not specific enough. 

"I wish this was easy to use" is not good. We can make them more specific and better however: "I wish finding a show to watch was easier"
card.name: Anti pattern: Opps that aren't specific
Anti pattern: Opps that aren't specific

card.desc:
If your top level opportunities represent distinct moments in time, then no opportunity should have two parents.

If you are finding a single opp should ladder up to more than one parent, it's framed too broadly. Get more specific and define one opportunity for each moment in time in which that need, pain point, or desire occurs.
card.name: Anti pattern: Opportunities, with multiple parent opportunities
Anti pattern: Opportunities, with multiple parent opportunities
Note: Being on watch for solutions
Note: Being on watch for solutions

card.desc:
Where you have a parent, with one child, who in turn has just one child. A vertical stack of opportunities.

They arise in two situations:

- You hear similar opportunities from several interviews, and each is really saying the same thing in different words
  - --> Reframe one opportunity to encompass the broader need and remove the rest
- You're missing sibling opportunities.
  - I f each sub-opp only partially solves the parent, then identify which sibling opportunities are missing and fill them in. If you aren't sure, then explore the parent opportunity in your upcoming interviews.
card.name: Anti pattern: Vertical opportunities

card.desc:
To be human-centered, opportunities must be framed from our customers' perspectives. No customer would ever say: "I wish I had more streaming entertainment subscriptions"... but they might say "I want access to more compelling content"

Review each opportunity on your tree and ask, 'have we heard this in interviews'? If you had to add opportunities to support the structure of your tree (i.e. a parent one), ask, "Can I imagine a customer saying this, or are we just wishing a customer would say this?"
card.name: Anti-pattern to avoid: Opportunities framed from your company's perspective
Anti-pattern to avoid: Opportunities framed from your company's perspective

old.desc:
Prioritising opportunities is crucial, but it can be difficult to prioritse a flat list of opportunities, given they all come in different shapes and sizes. Equally, some are interrelated, while some are sub-sets of others.

For example:
- I can't find anything to watch
- I'm out of episodes of my favourite show.

"I'm out of episodes" is one reason someone can't find anything to watch, but not the only. It's therefore a sub-opportunity of a bigger opportunity.

Also:
- I want to watch on the plane
- I want to watch on a train

These could be a sub-set of 'I want to watch on the go'. They could be collapsed into a single opportunity, unless the contexts provided different constraints such as _no internet on a plane_ whereas there may be cell data on the train. So perhaps they should be distinct sub-opportunities.

Structuring before prioristsing can help address common conernscs like:
- Should we always prioritise easy problems over hard?
- If so, do we ever get to the hard problems that may have the potential to differentiate us from our competitors and really drive our outcomes?

Structuring trees with parent & sibling relationships helps us deconstruct large, intractable problems into a series of smaller more solvable problems, for example 'is this show any good' might on the surface look like a challenging problem to solve, but as we dig in, we learn different people solve this problem in different ways:
- Who is in it?
- Is this similar to other shows I've watched?
- Who else is watching this show?
- What type of show is this?

card.desc:
Prioritising opportunities is crucial, but it can be difficult to prioritse a flat list of opportunities, given they all come in different shapes and sizes. Equally, some are interrelated, while some are sub-sets of others.

For example:
- I can't find anything to watch
- I'm out of episodes of my favourite show.

"I'm out of episodes" is one reason someone can't find anything to watch, but not the only. It's therefore a sub-opportunity of a bigger opportunity.

Also:
- I want to watch on the plane
- I want to watch on a train

These could be a sub-set of 'I want to watch on the go'. They could be collapsed into a single opportunity, unless the contexts provided different constraints such as _no internet on a plane_ whereas there may be cell data on the train. So perhaps they should be distinct sub-opportunities.

Structuring before prioristsing can help address common conernscs like:

Structuring trees with parent & sibling relationships helps us deconstruct large, intractable problems into a series of smaller more solvable problems, for example 'is this show any good' might on the surface look like a challenging problem to solve, but as we dig in, we learn different people solve this problem in different ways:
- Who is in it?
- Is this similar to other shows I've watched?
- Who else is watching this show?
- What type of show is this?

----

If you identify two opportunities that are siblings, look for a parent opportunity. The parent opp may not have been explicitly mentioned in an interview, and that's fine. Add it as it is implied by the other two opportunities.
card.name: OST structure: Parents & Siblings

card.desc:
Review your interview snapshots and for each opportunity ask the following questions:

1. Is this opportunity framed as a customer need, pain point or desire **and not a solution**
2. Is this opportunity unique to this customer, or have we seen it in more than one interview?
3. If we address this opportunity, will it drive our desired outcome?

If the answer to all three questions is yes, then add to the tree. For now simply group it under the branch in which it occurs. If it seems like it could live under more than one branch, reframe the opportunity to be more specific. You may even need to split it into multiple opportunities, one for each moment in which it occurs, so that each can be grouped under their respective branches.
card.name: Adding opportunities to the tree

old.desc:
We need each opportunity to be distinct from every other opportunity. If there's overlap, then we can't work on one at a time, instead they all get enmeshed with each other and we need to work on all of them at the same time.

A way to assist in developing distinct branches, is to use the opportunity maps and interview drawings as guide, given they are based around distinct moments in time. If you focus on distinct, key moments in time , there will be no real overlap from one branch to the next.

Often, this is as simple as mapping each node in your experience map to the top level of opportunities on your OST.

For example, this may play out as:
- Deciding to watch something
- Choosing something to watch
- Watching something
- The end of the watching experience

Translated to:
**Outcome**: Increase viewing minutes
- I need something to do
- I'm not sure what to watch
- I'm watching a show
- My show ended

card.desc:
Interviews only need to be 5mins long in some instances. They can just focus around 1-2 story based questions that try to help unpack the research question.

When they're doing continuous research, we don't feel the pressure to try get in all our favourite questions (which ultimately are often too much for our customers), we can put away the big interview plans and discussion guides.
card.name: No need to over-engineer the interview....
No need to over-engineer the interview....

card.desc:
Interviewing, choosing an opportunity, then stopping interviewing assumes that you chose the right opportunity, that everything will go to plan and you won't need to pivot.

Continuously interviewing means that you can easily stop, change, pivot. You can kill an opportunity on Tuesday, choose a new one on Wednesday, and use the already-scheduled interview on Thursday to explore it
card.name: The value of weekly interviewing

old.desc:
A one pager designed to help you synthesize what you learned in a single interview. It's how you turn your copious notes into actionable insights.

---

Quick facts: things that help you identify what type of customer you interviewed. I.e. how you segment customers (contract size, sign-up date, hours watched per week.... whatever is relevant for your product)




pp 83-85

---

card.desc:
We want to uncover needs, not solutions.

When a customer says "I wish I could just speak the name of the movie into the remote" that's a feature request, not a need.

Questions to open this up:

- What would that do for you?

--> opens up the solution space
card.name: Note: Being on watch for solutions

old.desc:
RQs: What we are trying to learn
IQs: What we ask

When interviewing, you'll want to balance breadth in uncovering opportunities - those pain points, desires that matter most to the customer you're interviewing... whilst leaving space to dive deep into the opportunity you're focused on.

However, don't want to spend time investigating an opportunity the customer doesn't care about, so sometimes this won't align.

**The primary Research Question in any interview should be - what pain points, needs, desires matter most to this customer**

^ Once you've uncovered these, you'll want to dive deep into the specifics of any of those opportunities. You want the customer to set the direction of the interview in terms of what you dive into, even though you might have specific opportunities in mind. **What matters most to your customer trumps what you need to learn**

-------

As per timeline interviewing, focus on recent actual behaviour that the customer can effectively recall and talk to. We develop story questions to elicit this knowledge... the scope of the story you want to elicit will change throughout the discovery process, i.e.:

####Narrow - for optimising your existing product

- **Tell us about the last time you used our streaming service**: Elicit pain points, needs, desires with your product

vs

####Broader - to uncover new opportunities

- **Tell us about the last time you watched any streaming service**: Elicit opportunities around your product and also competitors


vs

####Broadest - might help you uncover new markets

- **Tell us about the last time you were entertained **: Elicit opportunities regarding many different forms of entertainment and uncovers info about what other things your product category is competing with


-----

Tip: Use the experience map you created to provide timeline prompts to customers you're interviewing. Also draw out a version of their timeline as they talk so you can refer back to it

old.desc:
JTBD talks about understanding higher level aspirations and mapping product experiences to this. However, what about when aspirations don't actually reflect what the customer does day to day.

I might say I have an aspiration to live sustainably. but what if I always choose the cheapest products? What lies behind this?

When understanding aspirations therefore, it must be cross-referenced with an understanding of what the customer _actually does_ or at least _tries to do_.

YG was a good example, people told us all the ways they went out of their way to achieve their aspirations. It was validation that went beyond aspiration and showed they had invested skin in the game.

card.desc:
JTBD talks about understanding higher level aspirations and mapping product experiences to this. However, what about when aspirations don't actually reflect what the customer does day to day.

I might say I have an aspiration to live sustainably. but what if I always choose the cheapest products? What lies behind this?

When understanding aspirations therefore, it must be cross-referenced with an understanding of what the customer _actually does_ or at least _tries to do_.

YG was a good example, people told us all the ways they went out of their way to achieve their aspirations. It was validation that went beyond aspiration and showed they had invested skin in the game.

-----

Theresa Torres example: Recruiters wanted to hire 'passive candidates'... but they almost always hired 'active candidates'... why? because their incentives were such that they benefited from filling roles fast.
card.name: A caveat to JTBD aspirations - reality vs aspirations

old.desc:
Experience maps are a great starting point to document current knowledge. They should first be completed individually by the product trio and then combined into a more holistic view of the current state of knowledge. Starting individually is important as it helps prevent group think by giving each member an opportunity to develop their own perspective.

This is treated only as a series of hunches and possibilities, not the truth, but it gives a clear starting point. You make explicit what you think you know, where there are open questions, and what needs vetting in upcoming interviews with customers.

This artefact helps you explore your own, and your team-mates' perspectives and it guides customer interviews. It helps give structure to the opportunity space and is refined week on week as you learn more.

---

**Setting the scope of an experience map**

This is an important first step. The scope should be in relation to the outcome you're looking for. If you're focused on a traction metric, due to having high confidence about a specific area / opportunity, then you might set the scope quite narrow - understand how users entertain themselves with our service.

In most cases however, you'll want a scope that gives you room to explore, whilst also staying focused on your desired outcome. I.e. "how do customers entertain themselves with video"....

A vend example could be: "What's preventing retail store owners from keeping their online store current & up-to-date?"

---

**Experience maps can start as a 6P story**

- It focuses on the story around the interactions with the product, not the product itself. It draws the experiences of the customer.

**But they develop into more detailed and specific maps as we learn**

- As we learn more about customer, we'll add a lot more detail to the map - i.e. the various different ways they can hear about our product, the various other products they interact with on the way to solving their problem, etc.

card.desc:
Experience maps are a great starting point to document current knowledge. They should first be completed individually by the product trio and then combined into a more holistic view of the current state of knowledge. Starting individually is important as it helps prevent group think by giving each member an opportunity to develop their own perspective.

This is treated only as a series of hunches and possibilities, not the truth, but it gives a clear starting point. You make explicit what you think you know, where there are open questions, and what needs vetting in upcoming interviews with customers.

This artefact helps you explore your own, and your team-mates' perspectives and it guides customer interviews. It helps give structure to the opportunity space and is refined week on week as you learn more.

---

**Setting the scope of an experience map**

This is an important first step. The scope should be in relation to the outcome you're looking for. If you're focused on a traction metric, due to having high confidence about a specific area / opportunity, then you might set the scope quite narrow - understand how users entertain themselves with our service.

In most cases however, you'll want a scope that gives you room to explore, whilst also staying focused on your desired outcome. I.e. "how do customers entertain themselves with video"....

A vend example could be: "What's preventing retail store owners from keeping their online store current & up-to-date?"

---

**Experience maps can start as a 6P story**

- It focuses on the story around the interactions with the product, not the product itself. It draws the experiences of the customer.

**But they develop into more detailed and specific maps as we learn**

- As we learn more about customer, we'll add a lot more detail to the map - i.e. the various different ways they can hear about our product, the various other products they interact with on the way to solving their problem, etc.

---

**Combining individual maps into a collective with nodes and links**

**Nodes**: Actions or points in time in the experience
**Links**: What connect the nodes together

1. Arrange all nodes from individual maps into one collective map
2. Collapse similar / duplicate nodes together (careful not to over-generalise to lose important detail / context)
3. Determine the links between each node. The good, the bad, those that loop back, where people give up, etc. Motivation + Ability mapping framework might play nicely here
4. Add context to each step: Thinking, feeling, doing.
card.name: A starting point: Visualising what you know with an Experience Map

card.desc:
When faced with a new outcome to achieve, the evidence suggests that first rallying around a 'learning' goal is more appropriate than a 'performance' goal.

Learning: "Discover the opportunities that will drive engagement"
Performance: "Increase engagement by 10%"

We often need to do discovery to understand how best to measure a product outcome. I.e. learn what leads to churn first and use that knowledge to refine your target metric over time.
card.name: The case for 'learning goals'

old.desc:
Business outcomes are typically financial measures, but can also represent strategic initiatives (i.e. grow market share in Asia, increase sales to this customer segment). They are however almost always lagging indicators.

Product metrics sit squarely within the product team's sphere of control. We assign product metrics to product teams for accountability, responsibility and ownership, as they have direct control over it. Whereas a broader business goal, they only have some control over.

Traction metrics are not appropriate to assign to a product team as they tend to focus on the output

card.desc:
Business outcomes are typically financial measures, but can also represent strategic initiatives (i.e. grow market share in Asia, increase sales to this customer segment). They are however almost always lagging indicators.

Product metrics sit squarely within the product team's sphere of control. We assign product metrics to product teams for accountability, responsibility and ownership, as they have direct control over it. Whereas a broader business goal, they only have some control over.

Traction metrics are not appropriate to assign to a product team as they tend to focus on the output of a specific solution. In cases however, where you have a mature product and a very confident understanding that that traction metric is crucial, it can be appropriate to optimise for it specifically.
card.name: Business vs Product vs Traction metrics

Business outcomes are typically financial measures, but can also represent strategic initiatives (i.e. grow market share in Asia, increase sales to this customer segment). They are however almost always lagging indicators.

Product metrics sit squarely within the product team's sphere of control. We assign product metrics to product teams for accountability, responsibility and ownership, as they have direct control over it. Whereas a broader business goal, they only have some control over.

Traction metrics are not appropriate to assign to a product team as they tend to focus on the output

card.desc:
The shape of our tree can guide our work: The breadth & depth reflects our knowledge of the customer

- One that is too shallow indicates a potential need to do more customer interviews to discover more opportunities
- One that is too sprawling is a reminder to narrow our focus
- If there aren't many solutions identified for the target opportunity, we can hold an ideation session.
- If we don't have enough assumption tests in flight this can prompt us to ramp up testing

Top down & bottom-up.

Many teams work from the top - identifying a desired outcome, mapping the opportunities, then solutions, then assumption tests. However great teams can also work bottom up: **using assumption tests to evaluate solutions and evolve the opportunity space. In evaluating the opportunity space, understanding how they might best reach that outcome, and how to measure that outcome  will evolve. 

They interview week over week, continuously revising the tree, even after selecting a target opportunity. They consider multiple solutions to the target opportunity, setting up good compare and contrast decisions. They run assumption tests in parallel across the solution set, so they don't over-commit to less than optimal solutions
card.name: Tending to an Opportunity / Solution tree (the arborist) ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

old.name: Tending to an Opportunity / Solution tree (the arborist)

card.name: Tending to an Opportunity / Solution tree (the arborist) ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐
Tending to an Opportunity / Solution tree (the arborist)

card.desc:
The best designers do this. As they work on solutions, they learn more about the problem and in learning more about the problem they open up new ways of solving it.

When we learn through testing that a solution won't work, we shouldn't just move onto the next idea. We must pause and consider: "I thought this solution would work, based on my understanding about the customer... it didn't, so what did I misunderstand about the customer?"

We then revise our understanding of the opportunity space before moving onto new solutions. When we do this, our next set of solutions get better.

old.desc:
**The Hierarchy**

1. The Root: Your desired outcome: _The business need that reflects how your team can create business value_
2. The Opportunity Space: _The needs, pain-points & desires that if addressed, will drive your desired outcome_
3. The Solution Space (sits below the opportunity space) _where we visually depict the solutions we are exploring_
4. Assumption tests (site below the solution space) _How we'll evaluate which solutions will help us best create customer value in a way that drives business value_

------

> “The superior organization of information is a theme that appears over and over again in the study of expert performance.”

Jonassen argues that ill-structured problems are problems that have many solutions. There are no right or wrong answers, only better or worse ones. The solver must start by defining the goal and constraints of the problem before exploring potential solutions.

The short of it is that the problem solver, in our case, the product manager (or even better, the product team), must start by framing the problem.

**Multitracking in a systematic way.**

His first question, “What would you have if you had that?” creates a structure between “I want a house” and “I want to feel grounded in my community.”

His second question, “How else can you feel grounded in your community?”, expands that structure.

----

Let’s use a product example to illustrate this. Imagine you work at Facebook and you are responsible for newsfeed stories.

You might answer the question, “What should we build next?” with an idea, “Let’s add a dislike button.”

Some of us rush off and build that first idea or two. That’s akin to rushing off and buying a house before examining why we want one.

We don’t multitrack in a systematic way.

By jumping straight to solutions, even when we do consider multiple options, we often compare solutions that shouldn’t be compared against each other.

----

Instead, we want to consider which problem each solution solves... and make a decision about which problem is a more valuable opportunity relative to the business goal..... From there, we only compare solutions that deliver on the same opportunities. "Of these solutions, which is most likely to delivery on the target opportunity?"

A systematic approach requires that we consider multiple solutions that deliver on the same opportunity.

Building an opportunity / solution tree, allows us to visualise and externalise our thinking, examine our thinking, and it allows others to critique our thinking. **This can act as our 'roadmap' in many ways** it's flexible enough to not commit us to anything

----

**Steps to building out our Opp / Solution trees**

1) Start with a clear desired outcome

- i.e. start with a Key Result from ORKs
- It's often easier to create separate trees for each goal or metric. 

_For us, it could be: Reach profitability in 6 months, or retain our Conversion to engaged member metric_

2) Gather opportunities that emerge from generative research

- To start, capture what you think the opportunities are in your problem space.  Then quickly refine these with generative research. 

3) Gather solutions, from everywhere, but only solutions that connect to an opportunity

- solutions should only be considered if they help us deliver on one of our target opportunities. If they don’t connect to the tree, they should be considered a distraction.

4) Experiment to evaluate

- Expermints reflect work to test riskiest assumptions behind a solution, not your whole solution. 

---

**A Framework for Continuous Product Discovery**


- The goal isn’t to first discover opportunities and then discover solutions. Instead, we want to be continuously doing both.
- Every week you want to be doing some activities that support discovering and refining new opportunities 
- and every week you want to be doing some activities that support discovering and refining solutions.
- And, of course, every week you want to be delivering value to your customer.

Nobody said dual-track was easy. But it does lead to better products. And isn’t that what we all want?

card.desc:
**The Hierarchy**

1. The Root: Your desired outcome: _The business need that reflects how your team can create business value_
2. The Opportunity Space: _The needs, pain-points & desires that if addressed, will drive your desired outcome_
3. The Solution Space (sits below the opportunity space) _where we visually depict the solutions we are exploring_
4. Assumption tests (site below the solution space) _How we'll evaluate which solutions will help us best create customer value in a way that drives business value_

The opportunity space can and should consist of multiple layers of opportunities, i.e. smaller ones that when taken together end up solving larger opportunities. The OST helps teams take large, project size opportunities and break them down. As you work your way vertically down the tree, the opportunities get smaller. Teams can then simply focus on one opportunity at a time. With time, as we address these smaller opportunities, these solutions begin to address the larger opportunities.

old.desc:
Finding the best path to your desired outcome is commonly known as an 'ill-structured' or 'wicked' problem. There are no right or wrong answers, only better of worse ones.

**Much of the work with these problems is framing the problem itself**

- 'Grow customer accounts' vs 'create customers who want to open more accounts'

^ to pursue business value by creating customer value, we must frame the problem in a customer-centric way - we need to understand the needs, desires and pain points (collectively 'opportunities'* that, if addressed, would drive the business outcome. 

*) The opportunity space represents both the problem & desire spaces

card.desc:
Finding the best path to your desired outcome is commonly known as an 'ill-structured' or 'wicked' problem. There are no right or wrong answers, only better of worse ones.

**Much of the work with these problems is framing the problem itself**

- 'Grow customer accounts' vs 'create customers who want to open more accounts'

^ to pursue business value by creating customer value, we must frame the problem in a customer-centric way - we need to understand the needs, desires and pain points (collectively 'opportunities'* that, if addressed, would drive the business outcome. 

*) The opportunity space represents both the problem & desire spaces

-----

Defining and structuring the opportunity space is how we navigate an ill-structured problem.

However, good teams will try multiple ways of framing the opportunity space. Trying multiple framings to see how they impact the solution space.

This leads to two core tasks for a product team:
- Working out how to map the opportunity space
- Working out how we select which opportunity to pursue
card.name: The Opportunity Space

card.desc:
Another way to handle feedback is by:

Leading with a yes - You want to make sure the person knows you listened and understood what they just said and that you're not automatically in defense mode!

In fact, here are the 3 steps to answer any feedback:

###3 steps To Answer feedback

1) Lead with a yes: The first thing you should always do is acknowledge the feedback. Thank them.

2) Repeat & Empathize: Next, briefly summarize what they just said. Re-phrase their response in the form of a question that forces them to talk about it in a way that’s more helpful.

3) Assure: Lastly, assure them you care about the solution, and how you can move forward. 1
card.name: Not reacting in the right way
Not reacting in the right way

card.desc:
Great product reviews need preparation:

1. Make sure you remove distractions.
2. Propose more than 1 solution. (to avoid quick roadblocks)
3. Answer the Background Check.

🔎 The Background Check
Before any meeting, answer these 3 questions:
• What problem does it solve?
• How does it affect the user?
• Why is it better than the alternative?

This gives you a chance to make sure there isn't any "hole" in your narrative.
card.name: Meeting Preparation

card.desc:
Make sure you remove all distractions.

As you saw in the example, it's easy for people to get derailed by details, and unless you want specific feedback on details. 

Try to remove anything that's not related to what you want feedback on.
card.name: No feedback guardrails

old.desc: Use mental models and frameworks and evidence-based insights to shift the conversation to be less about "likes" and "feelings".

card.desc:
Use mental models and frameworks and evidence-based insights to shift the conversation to be less about "likes" and "feelings".

Another great way to handle those situations is to: Turn "likes" into "works"

"But why do you think it wouldn't work like that?"

card.desc:
You've seen how stories are the best way to convey an emotion.

Now, they don't ALWAYS need to be drawn...

Sometimes, starting a conversation with the story of a customer can go a long way—

since you're essentially doing 2 things:

1) Not criticizing someone's work

2) Creating new creative ways of thinking about the same problem (as you've seen with the 6P exercise)

Moving on to the 3rd situation...
card.name: Not leading with a story

card.desc:
Just like building a good product, relationships take careful research.

Are people not listening?

Maybe it's because you're not working on the right thing (🌵Unrelated.)

Disagree on a solution?

Just like users, your colleagues have desires, pains, and barriers (JTBD). Try to find the underlying problem? What are they not saying?
card.name: Relationship B.I.A.S

1) 💛 What's their vision for the future of the business?

2) ☔️ What's the biggest challenge they face right now?

3) 🚧 What's currently stopping them from reaching that vision?

----

card.desc:
As you saw here, a great way to fill pits and elevate peaks is to re-order or shorten your customer's journey.

This applies to anything, from onboarding to monetization. 

What could be re-ordered in a key part of your product experience to improve the customer experience?
card.name: Journey Re-ordering

card.desc:
People prefer smaller, immediate rewards rather than larger, future ones.

In the case of customer journey optimization, it's useful to borrow the financial concept of "actualized value".

In other words: how can your product deliver a smaller reward now (e.g. a preview of something important) instead of having your customers wait… even if it's for a better or more accurate reward later.1
card.name: Hyperbolic Discounting

card.desc:
Imagine you have two options:

A) 🙂 → 😍: You delight your "good" customers, i.e. going from a Net Promoter Score of 8/10 to 10/10.

B) 😐 → 🙂 You satisfy your "average" customers, i.e. going from a Net Promoter Score of 6/10 to 8/10).

Which one do you think is better?

According to research, you’ll earn about 9 times more revenue with the first option than the second option.1
card.name: The ROI of delight (why invest in the peaks, pits, transitions)
The ROI of delight (why invest in the peaks, pits, transitions)

old.desc:
Peak-End Rule

Your don’t merely evaluate an experience based on the average or a sum of all the micro-experiences.

That's because the brain doesn't store information like a computer would.

When customers try to remember an experience, their brain reconstructs it.

Specifically, their brain heavily weighs the Peaks, the Pits and the Transitions(start/end).

The good news is that the perception of these shortcuts can be influenced.1



----


----


Instead, you should focus on the
3 Customer Journey Priorities:

1. Fill the biggest Pit.
2. Elevate the main Peak.
3. Mark the Transition.

Ideally, you want to invest the minimum of effort that will cover all three.

card.desc:
Peak-End Rule

Your don’t merely evaluate an experience based on the average or a sum of all the micro-experiences.

That's because the brain doesn't store information like a computer would.

When customers try to remember an experience, their brain reconstructs it.

Specifically, their brain heavily weighs the Peaks, the Pits and the Transitions(start/end).

The good news is that the perception of these shortcuts can be influenced.1



----

Many companies just try to constantly fill the ALL the small pits.

(Let's call 'em "potholes").

That's a mistake… a game of whack-a-mole you'll never win.

----


Instead, you should focus on the 3 Customer Journey Priorities:

1. Fill the biggest Pit.
2. Elevate the main Peak.
3. Mark the Transition.

Ideally, you want to invest the minimum of effort that will cover all three.
card.name: Peak-End rule

old.desc:
Peak-End Rule

Your don’t merely evaluate an experience based on the average or a sum of all the micro-experiences.

That's because the brain doesn't store information like a computer would.

When customers try to remember an experience, their brain reconstructs it.

Specifically, their brain heavily weighs the Peaks, the Pits and the Transitions(start/end).

The good news is that the perception of these shortcuts can be influenced.1

card.desc:
Peak-End Rule

Your don’t merely evaluate an experience based on the average or a sum of all the micro-experiences.

That's because the brain doesn't store information like a computer would.

When customers try to remember an experience, their brain reconstructs it.

Specifically, their brain heavily weighs the Peaks, the Pits and the Transitions(start/end).

The good news is that the perception of these shortcuts can be influenced.1



----


----


Instead, you should focus on the
3 Customer Journey Priorities:

1. Fill the biggest Pit.
2. Elevate the main Peak.
3. Mark the Transition.

Ideally, you want to invest the minimum of effort that will cover all three.
card.name: Peak-End rule

card.name: Peak-End rule

There are parallels with the New York Times bestselling book by the Heath Brothers "The Power of Moments".

We recommend you read it if you want to create delightful customer journeys.

card.name: Journey moments

card.desc: These moments mark the start or end of a milestone.
card.name: Transitions

card.desc: These are increases or decreases of psych in your experience.
card.name: Jumps & drops

card.desc: Those moments are the highest/lowest absolute psych levels in your experience.
card.name: Peaks & Pits

card.desc:
Allow users to disengage from your product with a sense of completion.

In the context of addicting products, it's the ethical thing to do (as you'll see in Mod. 4). And in the context of transactional products like here, it's a way to keep users sane.

If not, people will associate your product to a never-ending treadmill—which may hurt your long-term user retention.1
card.name: Providing exit points

card.desc:
Not all features affect customer satisfaction equally.1
Delighters, even roughly executed, bring more satisfaction than well-executed "expected" features.

As delightful features become common, they also become expected. Make sure you never stop innovating!
card.name: The Kano Model: delighters

card.desc:
System 1 - Storing

At the end of every interaction, our brain stores information.

That new information drives the way we Block → Interpret → Act for the following interactions.

And the more loops we go through, the more our brain registers patterns. If the pattern is recognizable and enjoyable, it becomes a habit. What started as slow deliberate decisions is now a fast process.1

Make sure each interaction counts.
card.name: Storing information: System 1

card.desc:
Nudge: Scarcity

We tend to want more of what we can't have.

There are 3 types of scarcity:

1. ⌛️ Time-limited
2. 🧮 Quantity-limited
3. 🔑 Access-limited

⚖️ Ethics: Never fake scarcity; users might get caught once, but never twice.
card.name: Nudges - Scarcity

card.desc:
Unexpected things capture our attention... and they can also entice people to take action.

Gaps cause pain.

When we want to know something but can’t, it’s like having an itch that we need to scratch.

To take away the pain, we need to fill the knowledge gap.1
card.name: Nudges - Curiosity gap

card.desc:
People tend to look at and mimic the actions of others. It can take different forms:

1. ⭐️ User Reviews: When people rate their own experience with a product.

2. 👥 Wisdom of the crowd: When a large number of people use a product.

3. 🔰 Certifications: When organizations endorse a product. 

4. 👑 People of interest: When experts, celebrities, or friends praise a product.
card.name: Nudges - Social proof

card.desc:
Progressive Disclosure

An interface is easier to use when complex features are gradually revealed.

🔥 Pro Tip: Show only the core features of your product, and as users get familiar, unveil new options.

It keeps the interface simple for new users and progressively brings power to advanced users.1
card.name: Progressive disclosure of features

card.desc:
Commitment & Consistency

Getting users to make a small commitment and follow up on it can increase engagement.1

The smaller the initial ask, the more likely people will agree to do bigger tasks. Especially since the brain likes to be consistent with its previous actions.

It’s why multi-step forms can be 271% better than a big single-step form.2
card.name: Split steps

card.desc:
Powerful Valid defaults

When users fill out forms, they should be able to do so without changing anything.

When you're forced to enter something to progress... it's by default "invalid."1

As seen previously, this gives a lot of power to defaults since only a handful of people change them.(~5%) 2
card.name: Build valid defaults

old.desc: You always want to preserve 🧪Psych for future actions.

card.desc: You always want to preserve 🧪Psych for future actions. Hicks law says too many options will create friction. Definitely remove any options that 'everyone would choose' like "I want better health"
card.name: Reducing options

card.desc: You always want to preserve 🧪Psych for future actions.
card.name: Reducing options

card.desc: You always want to preserve 🧪Psych for future actions. Reducing friction helps
card.name: Reducing friction

card.desc:
People find waiting more tolerable when they can see the work being done on their behalf...

And they tend to understand and value the service even more after the wait.
card.name: Labor Illusion

card.desc:
It is the ease at which users can find features within a product.

Good discoverability is critical because it directly affects users' ability to see and understand what can be done to take action.1
card.name: Discoverability

card.desc:
We hate losing way more than we like winning. (ask Lance Armstrong)

In other words, losing $500 will hurt more than the joy of gaining $500, hence why we buy insurance.

 🔥 Pro tip: Reframing things in terms of loss can generate actions. Make sure it also follows a clear benefit for people, so it doesn't only trigger negativity.
card.name: Loss aversion

card.desc:
We tend to depend heavily on an initial piece of information (the anchor) to make subsequent decisions.

Anchoring works with anything that can be evaluated. (e.g., beauty, complexity, etc.)

Users must be able to relate to the anchor, to make it useful. For example, comparing $15 insurance cost to $25,000 insured value, is hardly relatable. Instead, comparing it to the average repair cost ($400) is better.
card.name: Anchors

card.desc:
If you want people to take action with the limited amount of attention, time, and energy they have...

You must make the benefits clear and align them with their interest.1

🔥 Pro tip: Ask yourself, what does the user gain with this interaction?
card.name: Benefits > Information

card.desc:
Cognitive load is the total amount of mental effort required to complete a task.  It influences the way we receive information.

Pro tip: Minimizing cognitive load = Users are less likely to block, more likely to see the right information, and act accordingly.
card.name: Cognitive load

old.desc:
The more we experience something, the more likely we are to like it, and the more susceptible it becomes a system 1 action (without thinking).1

This can be used for good (easing friction in a flow), or bad (dark patterns getting people to gloss over information, like an upsell)

card.desc:
The more we experience something, the more likely we are to like it, and the more susceptible it becomes a system 1 action (without thinking).1

This can be used for good (easing friction in a flow), or bad (dark patterns getting people to gloss over information, like an up-sell)
card.name: Familiarity

card.desc:
The more we experience something, the more likely we are to like it, and the more susceptible it becomes a system 1 action (without thinking).1

This can be used for good (easing friction in a flow), or bad (dark patterns getting people to gloss over information, like an upsell)
card.name: Familiarity

card.desc:
People tend to be more receptive when experiences are customized to their needs, a sign of careful attention.

This feeling originates from a mix of the endowment effect,1 loss aversion, and reciprocity, where we feel something has more value if it belongs to us.
card.name: Personalization

card.desc:
This phenomenon happens when your awareness of something increases.

You're then likely to see or hear that thing more often, even if it's not the case.

It's perfectly normal. Your brain is simply reinforcing the newly acquired information.1
card.name: Baader-Meinhof Effect

card.desc:
Priming works by activating an association or representation in users' short-term memory just before another task is introduced.

This technique generated a lift of ~3-5% in sales for McDonald's by priming different menu items depending on the time of day and weather!1
card.name: Priming

data.text:
Same with chatbots: 

...What was once an edge for companies to engage with customers has become an irritant for most people...

.Since it has been used without considering user context...

You check out an article... POP!! In your face... Remember——nobody would do this in real life... Even in a store:

They'd at least let you check the merchandise a bit... And then ask: "Hey, do you need help?"

So why do this in the virtual world...

card.desc:
Research has shown that companies focused on the long term averaged 47% more revenues than short-term focus companies.1

Optimizing for short-term goals will find its way to the product and eventually affect users, compromising your user experience and long-term growth.
card.name: Short vs long term thinking

card.desc:
People have gotten used to the idea that there are things on screens that are less relevant to the task at hand, such as: logos, navigation bars, footers, and blank space.

They tend to look at the center of the screen and avoid the edges.1
card.name: Edge Blindness

data.text: This also applies to anything on the edges of the screen. Menus, top banners, footers, etc.

card.desc:
Users have learned to ignore content that resembles ads, is close to ads, or appears in locations dedicated to ads.1

Make sure critical information is not displayed as such.
card.name: Banner Blindness

card.desc:
Hick’s Law predicts that the time and the effort it takes to make a decision increases with the number of options.

The more choices, the more time users take to make their decisions.1
card.name: Hick's Law

card.desc:
Finding Customer Desires

The best way to frame your product is to deeply understand the subtleties of the Motivation axis of your customers… even better than they do.

We added a worksheet with our favorite questions to help you find opportunities.
card.name: Motivation levers

card.desc:
Unusual or distinctive situations tend to be better remembered than common ones. That's a key element of creating memorable experiences.1

This "bizarreness effect" is also used by brain athletes to better memorize and remember different elements.2
card.name: Breaking the Script

card.desc:
Users tend not to change an established behavior. Unless the incentive to change is compelling, people are more likely to stick to the default situation presented.

This is also called the Status quo bias. It can be a powerful actor when trying to nudge users and shape behaviors.1
card.name: Power of Defaults

card.desc:
Story-Driven Product Culture

Storytelling is part of Airbnb's product culture since 2012.

The equivalent of their "6P Stories" (one for each of their 3 personas) are displayed in a few places in their offices.

They even hired a Pixar artist for the final version of their customer journeys. But don't worry, we'll reveal a much cheaper way to build great journeys in Module 3.1
card.name: Story driven products - one for each persona
Story driven products - one for each persona

old.desc:
the story format makes it easier for your brain to find new solutions that you wouldn't necessarily think of if you just focused on screens.

That's a psychological concept called "closure".

card.desc:
the story format makes it easier for your brain to find new solutions that you wouldn't necessarily think of if you just focused on screens.

That's a psychological concept called "closure".

You constantly try to fill the gaps in comics. Stories and panel gaps are like open-ended questions for your brain.

Comics force constant participation and imagination. That sparks creativity and help you find solutions.1
card.name: Closure

card.desc:
the story format makes it easier for your brain to find new solutions that you wouldn't necessarily think of if you just focused on screens.

That's a psychological concept called "closure".
card.name: Closure

card.desc:
Stories  makes your brain imagine that you are going through the journey.

In other words, you develop a higher-level of empathy for the hero of a story.

Neuroscientists have shown that stories are the single best vehicle we have to transfer our ideas to one another.

It's no coincidence that we use stories in our case studies… and in this course.
card.name: Character identification effect

card.desc:
We're evolutionary wired to make sense of the world through stories. This makes it easier for our brain to process and recall more information.

That's part of the reason why it's easier to convince people by using stories, as we'll see later in Module 4. 1
card.name: Narrative bias

card.desc: Your data tells you what happens. Your screens might tell you where, but… …only user journeys can tell you why.  The "real" story of your customers typically happens outside of your app.  Yet, we tend to focus on our screens because that's what we're used to see. It's a good example of the side-effects of the Law of the Instrument.1"
card.name: Showing Journeys

old.name: "Screens vs Journey  Your data tells you what happens. Your screens might tell you where, but… …only user journeys can tell you why.  The "real" story of your customers typically happens outside of your app.  Yet, we tend to focus on our screens because that's what we're used to see. It's a good example of the side-effects of the Law of the Instrument.1"

card.name: "Screens vs Journey  Your data tells you what happens. Your screens might tell you where, but… …only user journeys can tell you why.  The "real" story of your customers typically happens outside of your app.  Yet, we tend to focus on our screens because that's what we're used to see. It's a good example of the side-effects of the Law of the Instrument.1"

card.desc:
People are more willing to empathize with a single, identifiable person than large abstract groups.

That's also why people remember stories with vivid characters much better than abstract statistics and data.
card.name: Singluarity effect

"Screens vs Journey  Your data tells you what happens. Your screens might tell you where, but… …only user journeys can tell you why.  The "real" story of your customers typically happens outside of your app.  Yet, we tend to focus on our screens because that's what we're used to see. It's a good example of the side-effects of the Law of the Instrument.1"
