I wish I knew its arrival time in advance.” In this case, we know a product can deliver progress, but certain qualities about it make us nervous about using it.

- Intertia
  - Habits in choice: The forces that exist at the moment of decision and prevent a customer from switching from one product to another.
  - Habit in use: What disruptions in buying patterns exist as a consequence of an old habit?

--> Solving for customers’ habits is often an easy win. Your prospective customer already knows about your product and wants to buy it but can’t switch because of some small habit holding him or her back. All you have to do is figure out what’s holding your customer back and solve it.

--> Comparing the habits of your best customers with the havits of those who have recently quit is a great way to figure out how to turn swtichers into loyal customers. The first group have adapted to get their job done - learn from them and use those data to help those who are struggling.
cards.name: JTBD - Push / Pull analysis

cards.desc:
New features:

- How have you tried to solve this problem in the past? (validate it's a real problem experiened by customers)
  - i.e. have you ever tried to do X beofre? how?

Stuggles or aspirations (JTBD)

- Dig deeper when tapping into this ^ -How have you tried to solve it before? 
- What's a specific example of you having tried to solve it?
- How do you imagine life being better once you solve it?
- What are the consequences of not being able to solve your struggle / achieve aspiration
- How do you imagine life being better once you find the right solution?

Push / Pull (JTBD)

- Pushes:
  -  What solutions have you used?
  - At what point did you realize that theiryourparticular solution wasn’t working anymore? 
  - What was going on in your life?

- Pulls:
  - What did you like / not like about the product(s) you investigated?
  - Why did you choose product X or product Y? 
  - What was wrong with product Y? 
  - What did X have that Y didn’t?

- Anxieties:
  --> best served out of user testing.

- Habits:
  - What have you stopped doing since using YG - How has YG allowed you to stop doing this?
  - What do you still do, since using YG?


Unlocking question:
- tell me about the last time you did [X]
cards.name: Research question catalogue

cards.desc: Engage in an audit to determine which features don't help customers make progress toward their JTBD.
cards.name: Existing feature JTBD audit

cards.desc:
**JTBD as a 'system of progress'**

- What new struggles do customers face once they've overcome / achieved a JTBD? what's the next JTBD to solve? 

> Innovators must understand what the customer does and doesn’t know. We must abandon the idea that customers have a laundry list of “needs.” Instead, we should see customers as having only one need: to make progress within the systems they belong to. Any discomfort or frustrations they experience in making that progress should not be thought of as needs but rather descriptions of interactions between customers, their JTBD, and the product they’ve currently hired for their JTBD. For example, a car owner might claim that he “needs” more parking options in New York City. But is that really the problem? Or is the problem an expectation that it’s a good idea to own and drive a car in a population-dense area like New York City? Perhaps the best way to help this person make progress isn’t to solve the “needs” associated with owning a car; rather, it’s to make car ownership obsolete. At the time of this writing, this is the progress that products such as Uber and Lyft are trying to make happen.

> increase profits by designing for the system, not for customers’ stated preferences.

-----

- It all comes down to four points: 
  - (1) all customers want to make progress within the systems they belong to; 
  - (2) customers, producers, innovators, and products are all parts of a system; 
  - (3) understanding the system comes from studying the interdependencies between the parts, not from studying the parts; and 
  - (4) each system is complex and one of a kind, so solutions that improve them must also be one of a kind.

- Bring focus to which system of progress you're solving by splitting up products that deliver different types of progress.

--> YG: Is mealkits a different system of progress in a different JTBD? Be careful

^ instead, do we need to convince them of another system / JTBD?

- Persuade customers to reject their current products by changing their JTBD. A great salesperson understands that customer “wants” come from the system, not the customer. So, if you want to change “what customers want,” all you have to do is convince them of a Job that is worth getting Done.

- Imagine you make outdoor grills. You want to persuade customers to upgrade from small grills to larger, more expensive ones. How do you do that? Well, you won’t have much success if you just pepper customers with messages about how great your larger grill is or try to convince them that an existing grill is inferior. Why? These customers are fine with the way things are A healthy sync exists between their JTBD and the small grill they’ve hired for it.

- Customers are making the kind of progress they want. However, you will have a shot at selling a larger grill if you can convince customers how rewarding it is to host a large party and grill food for everyone. If customers agree to that idea of progress, they realize that their current grills can’t get them there. In that moment, you’ve changed the customers’ JTBD and changed the system of progress they interact with. If they want to restore sync to the system, then they need a new solution. That’s when you pull the curtain back on the larger grill and casually point out that they can cook food for twenty people.
cards.name: JTBD as a system of progress

cards.desc:
step through and narration of ordering process to uncover:

**Demand reduction**

- Anxiety
  - Anxiety in choice: We experience anxiety-in-choice when we don’t know if a product can help us get a Job Done. It exists only when we’ve never used a particular product before. For example, “I’ve never taken the bus to work. Is it ever on time? Where do I buy a ticket?”
  - Anxiety in use: After customers use a product for a JTBD, the anxiety-in-choice largely disappears. Now their concerns are related to anxiety-in-use. For example, “I’ve taken the bus to work several times. But sometimes it’s late, and other times it’s early. I wish I knew its arrival time in advance.” In this case, we know a product can deliver progress, but certain qualities about it make us nervous about using it.

- Intertia
  - Habits in choice: The forces that exist at the moment of decision and prevent a customer from switching from one product to another.
cards.name: User testing to discover push/pull

cards.desc: >  The Timeline is an interview technique in which you step the interviewee through one particular instance of a given product being purchased and used. It begins with the first thought they consumer had they needed a product similar to the one they bought, extends through using the product, past the “honeymoon period,” and evaluating their satisfaction in retrospect.
cards.name: JTBD timeline interview approach

cards.desc:
> The objective is not to test the functionality itself (that's QA), but to test the _experience_ within that functionality

**Setting objectives**

- What are you trying to learn?
- What do I need to know from this session?

--> then identify exactly which features and ares you want feedback on.

i.e.

- Find out whether users are able to complete specified tasks successfully (e.g. purchase a product, find information),
- Identify how long it takes to complete specific tasks,
- Find out whether users are satisfied with a product and identify changes required to improve satisfaction. 

-----

**Setting tasks**

- Make them realistic and actionable. i.e. specific parts of the product
  - Getting set up on the product
  - Completing a checkout

--> Clearly describe the task to complete and make it easy. People become discouraged when tasks are unclear.

- Have a goal for each task.
  - "I expect that users will be able to do X within two minutes"

- Limit the number of tasks (5 within a 60 minute session is about right)

- Provide a **Scenario** not an instruction. i.e. "you're looking for a new way to do X, show me how you'd go about this"

^ test the task yourself several times and work out appropriate questions to ask

-----

**Setting the framing appropriately**

- "we/re not testing you, we're testing our design - nothing you do or say is wrong"
- "You won't hurt my feelings - I've just come onboard and didn't have anything to do with building this / designing it"
- Start with easy tasks - they won't yield juicy insights but will get people talking and help relax them.
- Ask them to narrate aloud
cards.name: Usability testing approach

cards.desc:
> Should be tied to company vision / mission / purpose:  in doing so, conversations change from 'why are we doing that' to 'would decision A or B help us achieve our vision sooner?'

> A roadmap is a series of statements that communicate WHAT you'll help customers accomplish and WHY these goals are important to their success. It's not a feature release schedule

- After you've described the product vision and what everyone's there to accomplish, the next level down in detail should not be a list of features, functions and fixes with dates... Instead, even if you are pretty certain about some of the specifics, start with the **chunks of value** you intend to deliver that will build up over time to accomplish your vision. Often this is a set of JTBD, needs, problems - we call them **themes**

- Commit to outcomes, not output. OKRs help with this
cards.name: What is the purpose of a roadmap? Key points. Tying a product roadmap to the company vision / mission / purpose

cards.desc:
> Roadmaps take many forms and will be customised to tell the story of what it will be like when you achieve your vision, what it will take to get there, and how you will know if you are making progress.

Product vision

- How a specific sort of customer will benefit from your product when it is fully realised and ubiquitous.
- Dervved from a company's mission, vision, purpose

Business objectives

- To help you measure progress. What are the goals your product will accomplish? What will be measurably different for your organisation.

Timeframes

- Broad timeframes to prevent over-committing.
- Dates are **not** the primary measure of success. Broad timelines like Now, Next, Later, provide guidance whilst preserving flexibility
- The roadmap has to tell the product story, but it doesn’t have to get the days right.” So, rather than specific dates and features, we recommend timeframes that are less specific than January 2017, or even Q2 2018. Loose timeframes like Now, Next, and Later can still satisfy the teams and stakeholders without offering specific delivery dates.



Themes

- These focus on outcomes, not output.
- What would need to be trus for our product to realise its vision & attain its business objectives?
- Expressing themes as customer needs or problems is very effective in guiding development

Disclaimer.

- A caveat to make it clear the roadmap is subject to change without notice. Makes it clear that change is possible or even likely.
cards.name: Primary components of a roadmap + purposes

cards.desc:
> note, every bit of extra information has the _potential_ to backfire

Stage of development

- Labels like 'discovery', 'design', or 'prototyping' to communicate the early stage of a component. 

Target customers

- Useful if your product serves more than one type of customer

Product areas

- Themes or features may be annotated by product area. Separate product areas may also have separate business objectives.

Features and solutions

- Should be wary of sharing this. Perhaps only where stuff is very close to development / very certain or functional
- some teams include 'probable solutions' - a likely solution is evident, and may be a helpful starting point for exploration.
  - Infrastructure solutions often appear on a roadmap. i.e. "Algolia POC"

Confidence

- Stage of development kind of provides this insight, but there is the option to display a confidence level throuhgout the timeframe to reinforce that this is a draft and subject to change

------

**Complementary info** - not part of the roadmap, but important to be familiar with so you can answer questions:

Project information

- Schedule, resources, status, dependencies

Platform considerations

- Scalability reqs, infrastructure needs

Financial info

- Market opp, P&L

External drivers

- Regulatory changes, competition, events etc
cards.name: Secondary components of a roadmap + purposes

cards.desc:
> Your product strategy is the bridge that connects your high-level vision to the specifics of your roadmap. And for many companies, the product strategy is the main contributor to their overall business strategy. This makes it crucial that you use product strategy as a starting place for your roadmap.

------

##Derives from company mission / vision / values

**Mission Defines Your Intent **

A mission is not what you value, nor is it a vision for the future; it’s the intent you hold right now and the purpose driving you to realize your vision. A well-written mission statement will clarify your business’s intentions.

**Vision Is the Outcome You Seek**

 A company vision should be about a longer-term outcome that has an impact on the lives of the people your product serves, as well as on your organization. Vision is why your organization exists, and it can be decomposed into the benefits you hope to create through your efforts — for both the world and your organization.

**Values Are Beliefs and Ideals**

 Values are also intended to guide behaviors. Values shape that ambiguous word thrown around company HR departments, culture — how people behave when no one is watching. Your organization’s values may inform your vision or mission, and how you go about achieving it.

-----

**Product vision - why your product exists**

- Clarifies why you are bringing a product to market in the first place and what its success will mean to the world and the organisation


_Value proposition template_

For: [target customer] 
Who: [target customer’s needs] 
The: [product name] 
Is a: [product category] 
That: [product benefit/reason to buy] 
Unlike: [competitors] 
Our product: [differentiation] 
Supports our: [objective(s)]

> For homeowner landscape enthusiasts Who need a reliable hose that’s survives repeated use The Wombat Garden Hose Is a water delivery system That offers a reliable operation under any conditions Unlike the competition The Wombat Garden Hose is indestructible and offers uninterrupted wated delivery.

Then pare down to:

"A world where the [target customer] no longer suffers from the [identified problem] because of [product] they [benefit]"

>A world where American landscape enthusiasts [target customer] can have a more predictable and automatic [identified problem] watering system that can perfect their lawns [benefit] with an effective water delivery system [product].
cards.name: Defining a product vision

cards.desc:
> Identifying business objectives that tie to your vision is critical to making that vision a reality. If you don't have speciific objectives to hit along the way, the vision will be challenging to implement - there will be too many different directions to take to get there.

------

OKRs are a great way to pair business objectives with success criteria.

**Objectives** are specific qualitative goals

**Key results** are quantitative measures of progress toward achieveing those objectives.

- **Everything on your roadmap must be tied to at least one of your objectives**
  - In practice, where OKRs are set quarterly, the Roadmap should be refreshed quarterly to reflect this, re-prioritised and updated with respect to the product circle's quarterly OKRs
- Stick to a manageable number of objectives. Less than 5 seems most effective
- Focus on outcomes, not output

-----

**Contactually Objectives example**

It expresses its product strategy for the next year in three objectives, each with measurable success criteria: 

- “launch new features or services that realtors will pay more money for,”
- “improve the feature sets of our existing plans so more users will purchase,”
- “improve our team functionality to better meet the needs of team leads.”

Each of these themes is tied to an objective that can then be measured by specific key results, and their roadmap reflects this. This internal objectives-driven approach to roadmapping makes direction crystal-clear for internal teams. In this case, rather than being based on customer needs, each objective focuses on a measurable business benefit that work is designed to achieve

-----

*Key Results (and metrics)**

- Sometimes you might only have one metric per objective. That's ok. 
- Starting with a handful of KPIs (AKA key results) is a good and manageable place to land.

-----

**Contactually key results example**

Tying this back to Contactually’s objective of **“improve the feature sets of our existing plans so more users will purchase,”**

key results here could be 

- “an increase in user base by 5% over the course of a specific timeframe” (a quarter, year, etc.) 

and feature-specific metrics such as 

- “time to compose and send an email is reduced by 10%,” indicating that the usability of that part of the product has been improved. 

_Note that there can be multiple key results to each objective, as it may take different measures to determine whether an objective is met._

--------

**Caution on metrics**

- Be aware of falling into the trap of measuring non-business metrics. i.e.:

  - Feature metrics: Performance of a feature (How many people are using it? Is it quicker or easier for a customer to do X now than it was before?)

  - Product metrics: Performance of specific product objectives (Because of feature X, more people are using functionality Y)

  - Team metrics : How many story points/features were launched at the end of the month/quarter? (I put this in for dramatic effect; this will only lead to — at best — success theatre, and at worse, the wrong behaviours from all parties)

^ these measures tell us very little about the business impact of all the work we've done. **Attached images** display a better example of tying key results to business objectives

HEART framework is good for setting metrics: https://www.dtelepathy.com/ux-metrics/#intro
cards.name: OKRs for product vision

cards.desc:
**An output:** The stuff we produce. I.e. a car seat for babies

**An outcome:** The difference our outputs make i.e. keeping a child safe in the car (or JTBD: Giving parents the confidence to transport children and freely navigate the roads)
cards.name: Product roadmaps should focus on Outcomes not Outputs

cards.desc:
**product vision**

- Let’s start with SpaceX’s published corporate vision statement: SpaceX was founded under the belief that a future where humanity is out exploring the stars is fundamentally more exciting than one where we are not.
- Using the word product somewhat loosely, the first major component of SpaceX’s product vision is to “create a self-sustaining city on Mars.”

**business objectives**

- To make emigration to Mars market-viable, SpaceX would have to “drive the cost to the equivalent to a house in the US — about US $200,000.” That sounds like a business objective with a built-in key result.

**Themes**

- Musk then asks, for this strategy to be viable, what would need to be true? His team has done the research and defined the themes this way: 
  - Full spacecraft reusability 
  - Refueling in orbit 
  - Propellent production on Mars 
  - Right propellant 

**These four themes don’t describe the specific technology or solution, but are all subgoals of the affordability objective.**
cards.name: Vision -> business objectives -> themes example

cards.desc:
> A theme is a high-level customer need. Can standalone, or constitute multiple sub-themes.. A subtheme is a more specific need.

i.e.

Theme: Address key usability issues
Subthemes: Pagination, Menu navigation, save status

System theme:

Theme: Billing & Payments
Subthemes: API integration, API integration testing

> it is important to focus most of the roadmapping effort on customer needs and problems because “the viability of a feature may shift dramatically, while the nature of an important customer problem will likely remain the same.”

-----

**Going from themes and sub-themes to job stories**

- Describing customer needs without getting into the solution can be tricky business. To make it easier: job stories. (https://trello.com/c/6DqhTfkZ/18-job-stories-user-stories)

^^ Themes work in the same way but at a higher level. Framework:

### Ensure [result] for [stakeholder]

i.e. Make mobile experience as good as desktop for users.

--> YG: Try writing themes as job story / epics or as above framework
------

> You can also compare themes as the parent element of specific epics. A theme simply represents a bigger user or business problem you want to discover a solution (aka Epic) for in order to reach your goals.

Examples for a theme could be things like 'User Growth', 'Revenue', 'Churn' or 'Enterprise'. Corresponding epics could then be 'Referral Mechanism', 'Free Trial' or 'Single Sign On'.

------

**Themes must be tied back to objectives**

If any theme on your roadmap does not map back to an objective, this should be a warning sign. EVERY theme on your roadmap should related to at least one objective. If not, review the theme to see if it should be in the roadmap at all. 

- Helps you stay focused on the right things and avoid distraction.
- Your objectives help you realise your product vision and your themes and subthemes help you accomplish your objectives.
- It's fine if a theme informs multiple goals
- One way to link themes to objetives is to color code your objectives and then tag themes with the assoviated colour.
cards.name: Themes and sub-themes on a roadmap

cards.desc:
- Every time you plan a big update to the roadmap, you should review and reconsider the objectives. 
- If your roadmap is laid out in quarters, you should probably revist it and update it every quarter
cards.name: Reviewing and updating a roadmap

cards.desc:
> by giving each stakeholder the opportunity to have input early on (i.e., while the product roadmap is still a work in progress), the shuttle diplomacy process gives them authorship of the plan too. It’s not your plan anymore — it’s our plan. The co-creative nature of the roadmap process cannot be understated.

----

When engaging in shuttle diplomacy, you should entice your stakeholders with a draft of your roadmap and ask for their input. In the first part of your meeting, always tie it to the goals and objectives. 

You can use the simple acronym GROW to guide your conversation: 

- **Goals** What are they trying to accomplish in the next X months? 
- **Reality** What’s on their plate now? What’s recent? 
- **Options** What do they think will help them achieve those goals? What options have you already discussed that need to be revisited? 
- **Way forward** Which of the options helps them achieve the goals they described earlier in the conversation? Which options are at the top of their list and
cards.name: Shuttle diplomacy

cards.desc:
**Dev team**

- they'll want it embellished with some details including: 
  - likely features
    - A short list of features you believe will effectively dress the market problems laid in your themes - allows the team to ballpark effor involved and negotiate over scope and timing.
  - stage of development
  - scalability expectations
    - A good understanding of the usage volumes expected is useful.
  - dependencies and risks
    - I.e. one piece of work may rely on another to be completed first
  - (perhaps) technical underpinnings of the work they'll be executing on
    - A technical infrastructure is often asked to support features and functions for which it was not oringally designed. _Technical debt_ is the outcome. It’s best to work with your internal team to identify this technical and infrastructure work and build it into your plans along with the more visible work it supports. Some teams create a separate row on the roadmap for this supporting work, assigning them their own themes or concrete deliverables, while others create a separate slide or document for it.

^ when first showing this to engineering - you're looking for feedback about what is feasible, not dictating what must be complete by certain deadlines.

-----

**Sales & marketing**

Your roadmap should help them understand what advantages your product will provide in terms of increased value, tied to critical dates on their calendar.

- Target customers
  - i.e. new markets opened up?
- Confidence
  - Will bake this into their planning
- Fearues and solutions (likely, probable, tentative)


-----

**Executives & board**

Generally, you'll want to limit the roadmap information here to high level stuff on vision, strategy & problem solving themes. It's smart to have all the other details on hand for those occasions where an inquisitive board member develops some concerns.

- Financial information: Market opp
  - Cold be the target customer, or explicit revenue and profit targets
- Financial information: Profit & loss
  - Adding rough revenues and a projected break-even timeframe can be useful to help this audience understand what you feel is required to reach a certain level of financial results
cards.name: Roadmap tweaks for different audiences

cards.desc:
It’s best to work with your internal team to identify the technical and infrastructure work required and build it into your plans along with the more visible work it supports. 

**Some teams create a separate row on the roadmap for this supporting work, assigning them their own themes or concrete deliverables**, while others create a separate slide or document for it.
cards.name: Technical debt / infrastructure considerations on a roadmap

cards.desc:
**The faster the pace of change in your market, the faster your development cycle should be — and the more compressed your roadmap should be** in terms of both total timespan and the intervals you choose. 

While an established product in a mature market that releases new and improved versions once per year will have a correspondingly long roadmap, **a startup that is releasing new capabilities every week will have a roadmap that may stretch only a few months into the future.**

----

Many startups favor a simple roadmap format, which uses broader timeframe bucketing like Now, Next, and Later. Generally, the pace of change and development is directly related to your product’s stage of life and the maturity of its market.

If companies in your space are still figuring out what the future might hold, it doesn’t make sense to spend a lot of time making detailed long-term plans that will surely change.
cards.name: Length of Roadmap

cards.desc:
**Strategic context**

- Do you have a clear product vision that most stakeholders can explain? 

- Do you have measurable business objectives that most stakeholders are aware of?

**Focus on value **

- Does your roadmap focus on customer needs?

- Are all of the things on the roadmap clearly tied to customer needs and/or business objectives?

**Embrace learning**

- Do you update your roadmap regularly, leveraging an evolving process? 

- Do you allow time in the roadmap to learn whether solutions are working before committing to solving a customer need?

**Rally the organization around priorities**

- Do you use an objective and accepted method of prioritization?

- Do you have an established process for achieving alignment with stakeholders?

- Do you regularly present and share your roadmap with key stakeholders?

**Get customers excited** 

- Do you regularly present and share your roadmap with customers?

- Do you seek customer feedback on the roadmap and incorporate it in your process?

**Avoid overpromising**

- Do you have specific features, solutions, fixes, or other deliverables on your roadmap? (detractor)

- Do you have precise or “best-case” dates for things on your roadmap? (detractor)

**Avoid overdesigning and overplanning**

- Do you throughly design a solution before putting a customer need or problem on the roadmap? (detractor)

- Do you have project info like resources, milestones, and dependencies embedded in the roadmap?
cards.name: Roadmap health assessment

cards.desc:
Customer support team can be a terrific source of insight for product people.

Many can provide you with a list of common complaints or trouble spots in your product, ranked by frequency or rep time spent. This is good data for prioritizing enhancements **under the general heading of usability**, and it makes a lot of sense to prioritize work here **if** usability is one of your key goals.

Take special note of that “if,” though. We are not questioning the value of usability in general, but we are suggesting that **this goal needs to be weighed in the context of all of your goals**. 

A particular focus on usability makes all the sense in the world when you have a product people are buying but not using or not renewing sufficiently. It is probably not your #1 priority, however, if customers find it easy to use but it’s missing critical functionality that causes them not to buy it in the first place.
cards.name: Prioritising 'usability' issues

cards.desc:
### Value / Effort = ROI

------

Value = [Customer need 1] + [Customer need 2] + [Organisational goal 1] + [Organisational Goal 2] + [n]

^ This is deliberately imprecise. It's not meant to be a forecast, it's simply a prioritisation between multiple things

- Scale of 0-2 can be used
  - 0 = small enough it doesn't really matter
  - 1 = medium or some positive effect
  - 2 = large positive effect

-----

Effort: Whatever is necessary to meet your customers needs and achieve your organisations goals by adding the proposed feature, enhancement or solution.

^ quick way to get over initial reluctance around estimates is to do the estimates yourself and then ask someone involved in the implementation for a reality check. By taking responsibility for the estimate, you absolve others from that feeling of premature commitment. (Also, it turns out it’s much easier to get an engineer to tell you why you’re wrong than to get them to give an estimate themselves.)

-----

#### Note

**No-one should be a slave to a formula. Frameworks like these should be used as an aid to decision-making, not as the decision itself.**
cards.name: ROI socrecard for feature prioritisation

cards.desc:
Not a method for prioritisation

A method for categorising your prioritised list of requirements into un-ambiguous buckets, making it clear what your release criteria are. Informs what should be cut first in a sprint where scope cuts are required

-----

Could-haves are features that are wanted, but not as important as should-haves. These are the first items you would cut if they introduced budget or deadline risk. You can distinguish could-haves from should-haves by the degree of pain that leaving them out would cause the customer, or the reduction in value of the solution. Another way some teams think of this category is as a list things to include “if easy.” Your delighters may also fall into this bucket. 

Won’t-haves are requirements deemed “out of scope” for a particular release. Won’t-haves could contain both satisfiers and delighters, but should not contain dissatisfiers or critical path items (otherwise, what’s the point of releasing?). Won’t-haves may be included in future releases, of course. It’s useful to agree on these items up front to avoid misunderstandings about scope, rehashing scope mid-project, or what is often called scope creep.
cards.name: MoSCoW

cards.desc:
> The Job Story describes a struggling moment which the customer faces, how they visualize progress, and how life is better when they have a solution for that struggling moment.

>User stories and specs don’t do any of that. They describe what the solution looks like.

## [ A moment of frustration ] + [ how progress is visualized ] + [ how life is better ]

^ All of the information above is critical and very informative because we’re focusing on causality. Each job story should provide as much context as possible and focus on motivation… instead of just implementation... Also, we’re describing the emotions surrouding a situation, and how things would be different once that situation is resolved.



------


**Problem with user stories**: The first problem is that we start with a Persona, which is a very bad idea, and then plop in an action which we think should be taken in order to achieve the expected outcome

**Good things about job stories**: Job Stories are great because it makes you think about motivation and context and de-emphasizes adding any particular implementation. Often, because people are so focused on the who and how, they totally miss the why. When you start to understand the why, your mind is then open to think of creative and original ways to solve the problem.

------

Example:

When I’m presenting my visual design and I’m worried that people will reject its merits, I want something objective to back it up, so that people will see and discuss the design with less subjective bias.

----

**Testing out with YG cards**

https://trello.com/c/HCFiYVLt/756-as-a-piedis-picker-i-need-to-know-which-orders-have-already-been-printed

When I'm printing orders and I've got a lot to get through, I want to know I'm not printing one that's already been fulfilled so I'm confident I'm not doing re-work or doubling up on orders.

Acceptance:
-
cards.name: Job stories > user stories
To research: How to go from Product Roadmap, to Product backlog, to Sprints

cards.desc:
**Heirarchy of terms**

- A release can contain multiple sprints.
  - Sprints AKA 'iterations'
  - Sprints usually last two to four weeks
  - Whether or not each sprint is released at completion, it should still potentially be shippable (functional and tested)
  - A sprint has four distinct phases (Planning, development, review retrospective.
    - Planning: Product backlog items selected, goal of iteration defined
    - Development: Definition, coding and automated + functional testing. Standups
    - Review: meeting with stakeholders to demo and get feedback
    - Retro - process improvement
- a 'Product backlog' is a prioritised set of features / job stories that are placed into iterations.
  - A product backlog should map the product vision and strategic goals of the company
  - As stories move towards the top of the product backlog, the product owner (me) adds more detail and the development team estiamtes the work involved.

Questions for YG:
- What is your release cycle?
- What is your sprint length?

**Sprint planning meetings**

1. First is to decide what to build:
  - Review product vision and progress since last sprint
  - Discuss priority of backlog (should already have been socialised for feedback)
  - Opporrtunity to 'groom' the backlog - reorganise it etc.
  - Setting sprint goal

2. Second is how to build it.
  - Team compiles a list of tasks to achieve the backlog items and meet the sprint goal. 
  - Each task should be smallish - 4-16 hours of work. Task list = Sprint backlog.
  - Example product backog item --> sprint backlog task: "Create API layer to access purchase data" --> "Map purchase data elements to database tables" + "" etc

**Release management**

- Roadmap should be divided into releases
- Poduct backlog of features (job stories) created which define each release
- With devs, separate the upcoming release into a series of sprints. The tasks are assembled in the sprint backlog
- Sometimes teams need to do research in order to size a story. In this case, create a research story, with a time limit and included as work to be done in the release. The actual implementation will be pushed to the next or later release.
cards.name: Scrum

cards.desc:
**Product management across iterations**
Simultaneously:

- Gathering feedback on recently released iterations
- Supporting the development team on the current iteration
- Fleshing out requirements by speaking with customers, **testing concepts and developing prototypes** for upcoming releases.

--> A good guide is to focus on 120 days of the product cycle.

--------

1. For Sprint T + 2, or sixty days out, gather feedback from customers about what the next features should be and how the product should behave. You might research a design goal, such as identifying obstacles that prevent prospects from converting to customers on your website. You should also socialize these requirements with development to capture their questions and concerns that need to be answered.

2. For Sprint T + 1, or thirty days out, validate designs, capture full acceptance criteria for each requirement, and complete each of the user stories so that they can be properly sized and developed. 

3. For the current Sprint, support your development team by answering any questions that they have as they go through the development process. 

4. For the Sprint that has just been released, validate the actual working software with customers to uncover any changes needed for future iterations. 

-------

it is a good idea to have a few evergreen requirements. These are features that have to be developed but are not currently urgent. Further, they are technically difficult but require little or no input from the product management team (architectural changes, performance enhancements, and scalability improvements, etc.) This way, if for any reason your research on a requirement becomes delayed, you can at least slot an evergreen feature into the iteration and ensure the team remains productive addressing high value items.

-------

Managing design in Agile:

Designers can form part of the development team - in which case the UXer owns the first phase of the development process for stories that touch the UI. The UXer will work on current stories that do not require significant user validation and will look ahead to upcoming iterations for projects with longer lead times.

-------

**^ Managing at YG**. Contract designer at commencement of each sprint? Work on validated product backlog items that have been accepted? UI tasks.
-- PM work (me) on validating feature sets with prototyping, wireframing, discovery (i.e. an onboarding flow).

^^ **Use case** : User-onboarding flow.

- PM: Sprint T+2 - gather feedback from customers / research / discover anxieties / habits / goal etc **Research a design goal**
- PM: Sprint T+1 - Prototype / validate designs, capture acceptance criteria annd job stories for sizing and development
- PM:  Current sprint: manage process
- Design: Current sprint: Take validated designs and build out User interface designs at commencement of sprint. 


----

Potential process for T+2 work: https://trello.com/c/lAGLuIsG/46-procut-kata-as-a-discovery-framework
cards.name: PM across sprints in scrum

cards.desc:
How does it work?

- Understand where you are (the current condition),
- where you want to be (target condition),
- whats stopping you from making progress towards it (obstacle),
- whats your next step,
- what do think will happen (expected),
- what did you learn.

------

Example:

Consider this as the current condition — 85% of trial users don’t complete key activation steps.

We don’t know why yet, but we do know that we need to achieve a rate of at least 50% to have a healthy trial to subscribing rate and then retention rate thereafter.

It is here the Kata gives us a simple framework to progress through what we don’t know to discover potential solutions, then to communicate the findings and progress.

In this example below, each row might be a week or shorter depending on the problem space.

(see attached image)

The process is about progressively solving problems, identifying the next step, and expanding understanding. Once there is sufficient understanding to anchor knowledge and take the next step, do so. Step and repeat. 

This framework will deepen your customer knowledge and expose a host of opportunities and solutions to impact the business objective.

-----

In first image attached, we linked the business objective to increasing the adoption of feature X, making a single bet about what would have the desired business impact. 

Without using a method of discovery like the Product Kata, this is more of a hunch. That’s not to say hunches are bad, but before we go spending the company’s money we should make sure we have properly explored the problem space.

In the Kata, we observed multiple things that contributed to the desired business objective. Now, if only there was a way to visualise the Product Kata and visualise the exploration of the problem space…

This segues into another neat tool: opportunity solution trees. This tool allows the team to create a mental representation of how the business objective could be achieved, while making the guesses/assumptions obvious.

-----
regarding the image:

- Blue: Good product discovery starts with a clear desired business outcome. For us this is defined in the OKRs for our team, as set against the agreed business objective.

- Green: Opportunities should emerge from generative research. From research performed as part of the Kata such as user interviews, surveys, feedback and the like, we produce opportunities worth exploring.

- Yellow: Solutions can and should come from everywhere (as long as they are bounded by an opportunity). Grouped together by opportunities, we can generate ideas that would have impact.

- Orange: Experiment to evaluate and evolve your solutions Lastly, rather than fully commit to a solutions feature set, we can experiment our way towards it. It’s here we combine with the Kata (Obstacles and Steps) and use the experiments as steps towards the target condition/business objective.

-----

**note** : The decision trees can also be used in reverse; if you have a lot of ideas (or a backlog you’ve just taken over), you can work backwards to the objective and discard ideas that don’t align.

> Use opportunity solutions trees to foster and visualise multi-tracking and experimentation, and to avoid single idea bets. Importantly, use as communication tool for the business and peers to explain thinking.

^ [Read this](https://www.producttalk.org/2016/08/opportunity-solution-tree/) for more!!
cards.name: Product Kata as a Discovery framework (T+2 / T+1 work)

attachments.name: Kata process to discover opportunity trees

cards.desc:
> Ok, I realise that this isn’t an earth shattering revelation, but with this simple process you can avoid so much of what happened to me early in my career. 

-  Are we building the right thing?
-  Have we moved the needle on X metric?
-  Did we get value for the money we spent?
-  How does this relate to business objective Z?
-  Why did we decide to build this?

____

note:

The RICE acronym scores each potential solution along the following dimensions:

- Reach: how many people will this impact? (Estimate within a defined time period) --> not as important at YG?
- Impact: how much will this impact the goal? (Massive = 3x, High = 2x, Medium = 1x, Low = 0.5x, Minimal = 0.25x)
- Confidence: how confident are you in your estimates?
- Effort: how many “person-months” will this take? (Use whole numbers and minimum of half a month — don’t get into the weeds of estimation)
REACH x IMPACT x CONFIDENCE / EFFORT = RICE SCORE

^We’ve further extended the confidence estimate with an idea from Itmar Gilad, where confidence is scored based on validation tasks you perform. This is super useful, as it ensures we’re checking with the customers that we are building the right thing.

--> Where are we documenting this type of stuff at YG? Notion.so is an option?
cards.name: One pagers for each idea (T+2 / T+1 work)

cards.desc:
**Measure the right thing, then check if it worked**

We need to define the measurement of success at multiple levels. First, at the desired business objective, then at the opportunity, and finally at the solution level. For each one-pager the success metrics should be defined; I suggest using the HEART framework and picking the 2 relevant metrics for the solution.

HEART framework: https://www.dtelepathy.com/ux-metrics/#intro

However, the measurement of the solution is not enough. We need to be looking at the impact to the business metric, which we record in the Result field. Obviously, this will lag after release, so we should set a timeframe to define if the solution worked or not and record it. This should be reviewed as part of the PM team. This might be painful to begin with; but ultimately will improve your product thinking and approach.
cards.name: Measuring success of initiative against OKR

cards.desc:
'𝗦𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗘𝗻𝗱 (𝙜𝙤𝙖𝙡) 𝗶𝗻 𝗠𝗶𝗻𝗱 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗪𝗼𝗿𝗸 𝗕𝗮𝗰𝗸𝘄𝗮𝗿𝗱' (Michael Stelzner, 2011, p.40).

Plotting desired end-state through logic of lagging & leading outcomes, right through to output (focuses)
cards.name: Plotting logic from outputs to results (OKRs)

cards.desc:
---
**The concept**

- Care for people personally
  - Friend v foe mentality can take over in subconscious. A person in a foe bucket might give us the justification to treat them poorly.
- Challenge people directly
  - You should possess a _willingness to piss people off_ **in a way that shows you care**
  - It's not just your job to say it - it's your moral obligation. If you do this, you'll help yourself and others do the best work of their lives.

---
**The quadrants**

- Challenge direct + care personally = 'Radical candour'
- Challenge direct + not care = 'Obnoxious aggression'
- Don't challenge + care personally = 'Ruinous empathy'
- Don't challenge + don't care = 'Manipulative insincerity'

---

> if it's criticism do it in private, if it's praise you can do it in public

---

Learnings: Catch yourself defaulting to 'laughing something off' out of awkwardness. Use that as an opportunity to practice. (think Pash)
cards.name: Radical candour
The novice focuses on features, the pro focuses on problems. The top pros take this to the next level and ask - 'If we solve that problem, what's the outcome we want to see? '

A product person must learn to take 'gut opinion' as input, and apply some rigour to it - understanding what problem the exec is trying to solve, whether solving this problem aligns well with the product strategy and whether the proposed solution is the best available

Feature Factory PMs tend to focus on the pace of feature delivery. They just keep on building; because to them (or their company) it’s a bigger sin to not have developers building things than it is to have them discovering the right things to build.

cards.desc:
Research has shown that companies focused on the long term averaged 47% more revenues than short-term focus companies.1

Optimizing for short-term goals will find its way to the product and eventually affect users, compromising your user experience and long-term growth.
cards.name: Short vs long term thinking
Service Startup: Design Thinking gets Lean
Service Startup: Design Thinking gets Lean
This is service design methods - PDF!

cards.desc: https://www.interaction-design.org/literature/topics/gestalt-principles
cards.name: Gestalt principles in IX
Photography inspo for building colour palettes

cards.desc: "I'm a high empathy product manager and product designer"
cards.name: Empathiser

cards.desc:
Product
- TalkiPlay
- Theratrak
- Develo
- YourGrocer
  -- Dual track agile
  -- Experiment design & process
  -- Customer Experience design & vision
  -- Onboarding experience design
  -- Customer research

Design
- YourGrocer
  - Mobile web
- MyNewThing
cards.name: Portfolio

cards.desc:
People are more willing to empathize with a single, identifiable person than large abstract groups.

That's also why people remember stories with vivid characters much better than abstract statistics and data.
cards.name: Singluarity effect

cards.desc: Your data tells you what happens. Your screens might tell you where, but… …only user journeys can tell you why.  The "real" story of your customers typically happens outside of your app.  Yet, we tend to focus on our screens because that's what we're used to see. It's a good example of the side-effects of the Law of the Instrument.1"
cards.name: Showing Journeys

cards.desc:
We're evolutionary wired to make sense of the world through stories. This makes it easier for our brain to process and recall more information.

That's part of the reason why it's easier to convince people by using stories, as we'll see later in Module 4. 1
cards.name: Narrative bias

cards.desc:
Stories  makes your brain imagine that you are going through the journey.

In other words, you develop a higher-level of empathy for the hero of a story.

Neuroscientists have shown that stories are the single best vehicle we have to transfer our ideas to one another.

It's no coincidence that we use stories in our case studies… and in this course.
cards.name: Character identification effect

cards.desc:
the story format makes it easier for your brain to find new solutions that you wouldn't necessarily think of if you just focused on screens.

That's a psychological concept called "closure".

You constantly try to fill the gaps in comics. Stories and panel gaps are like open-ended questions for your brain.

Comics force constant participation and imagination. That sparks creativity and help you find solutions.1
cards.name: Closure

cards.desc:
Story-Driven Product Culture

Storytelling is part of Airbnb's product culture since 2012.

The equivalent of their "6P Stories" (one for each of their 3 personas) are displayed in a few places in their offices.

They even hired a Pixar artist for the final version of their customer journeys. But don't worry, we'll reveal a much cheaper way to build great journeys in Module 3.1
cards.name: Story driven products - one for each persona

cards.desc:
Users tend not to change an established behavior. Unless the incentive to change is compelling, people are more likely to stick to the default situation presented.

This is also called the Status quo bias. It can be a powerful actor when trying to nudge users and shape behaviors.1
cards.name: Power of Defaults

cards.desc:
Unusual or distinctive situations tend to be better remembered than common ones. That's a key element of creating memorable experiences.1

This "bizarreness effect" is also used by brain athletes to better memorize and remember different elements.2
cards.name: Breaking the Script

cards.desc:
Hick’s Law predicts that the time and the effort it takes to make a decision increases with the number of options.

The more choices, the more time users take to make their decisions.1
cards.name: Hick's Law

cards.desc:
Users have learned to ignore content that resembles ads, is close to ads, or appears in locations dedicated to ads.1

Make sure critical information is not displayed as such.
cards.name: Banner Blindness

cards.desc:
People have gotten used to the idea that there are things on screens that are less relevant to the task at hand, such as: logos, navigation bars, footers, and blank space.

They tend to look at the center of the screen and avoid the edges.1
cards.name: Edge Blindness

cards.desc:
Priming works by activating an association or representation in users' short-term memory just before another task is introduced.

This technique generated a lift of ~3-5% in sales for McDonald's by priming different menu items depending on the time of day and weather!1
cards.name: Priming

cards.desc:
This phenomenon happens when your awareness of something increases.

You're then likely to see or hear that thing more often, even if it's not the case.

It's perfectly normal. Your brain is simply reinforcing the newly acquired information.1
cards.name: Baader-Meinhof Effect

cards.desc:
People tend to be more receptive when experiences are customized to their needs, a sign of careful attention.

This feeling originates from a mix of the endowment effect,1 loss aversion, and reciprocity, where we feel something has more value if it belongs to us.
cards.name: Personalization

cards.desc:
The more we experience something, the more likely we are to like it, and the more susceptible it becomes a system 1 action (without thinking).1

This can be used for good (easing friction in a flow), or bad (dark patterns getting people to gloss over information, like an up-sell)
cards.name: Familiarity

cards.desc:
Cognitive load is the total amount of mental effort required to complete a task.  It influences the way we receive information.

Pro tip: Minimizing cognitive load = Users are less likely to block, more likely to see the right information, and act accordingly.
cards.name: Reducing cognitive load

cards.desc:
If you want people to take action with the limited amount of attention, time, and energy they have...

You must make the benefits clear and align them with their interest.1

🔥 Pro tip: Ask yourself, what does the user gain with this interaction?
cards.name: Benefits > Information

cards.desc:
We tend to depend heavily on an initial piece of information (the anchor) to make subsequent decisions.

Anchoring works with anything that can be evaluated. (e.g., beauty, complexity, etc.)

Users must be able to relate to the anchor, to make it useful. For example, comparing $15 insurance cost to $25,000 insured value, is hardly relatable. Instead, comparing it to the average repair cost ($400) is better.
cards.name: Anchors

cards.desc:
We hate losing way more than we like winning. (ask Lance Armstrong)

In other words, losing $500 will hurt more than the joy of gaining $500, hence why we buy insurance.

 🔥 Pro tip: Reframing things in terms of loss can generate actions. Make sure it also follows a clear benefit for people, so it doesn't only trigger negativity.
cards.name: Loss aversion

cards.desc:
It is the ease at which users can find features within a product.

Good discoverability is critical because it directly affects users' ability to see and understand what can be done to take action.1
cards.name: Discoverability

cards.desc:
People find waiting more tolerable when they can see the work being done on their behalf...

And they tend to understand and value the service even more after the wait.
cards.name: Labor Illusion

cards.desc: You always want to preserve 🧪Psych for future actions. Reducing friction helps
cards.name: Reducing friction

cards.desc: You always want to preserve 🧪Psych for future actions. Hicks law says too many options will create friction. Definitely remove any options that 'everyone would choose' like "I want better health"
cards.name: Reducing options

cards.desc:
Powerful Valid defaults

When users fill out forms, they should be able to do so without changing anything.

When you're forced to enter something to progress... it's by default "invalid."1

As seen previously, this gives a lot of power to defaults since only a handful of people change them.(~5%) 2
cards.name: Build valid defaults

cards.desc:
Commitment & Consistency

Getting users to make a small commitment and follow up on it can increase engagement.1

The smaller the initial ask, the more likely people will agree to do bigger tasks. Especially since the brain likes to be consistent with its previous actions.

It’s why multi-step forms can be 271% better than a big single-step form.2
cards.name: Split steps

cards.desc:
Progressive Disclosure

An interface is easier to use when complex features are gradually revealed.

🔥 Pro Tip: Show only the core features of your product, and as users get familiar, unveil new options.

It keeps the interface simple for new users and progressively brings power to advanced users.1
cards.name: Progressive disclosure of features

cards.desc:
People tend to look at and mimic the actions of others. It can take different forms:

1. ⭐️ User Reviews: When people rate their own experience with a product.

2. 👥 Wisdom of the crowd: When a large number of people use a product.

3. 🔰 Certifications: When organizations endorse a product. 

4. 👑 People of interest: When experts, celebrities, or friends praise a product.
cards.name: Nudges - Social proof

cards.desc:
Nudge: Scarcity

We tend to want more of what we can't have.

There are 3 types of scarcity:

1. ⌛️ Time-limited
2. 🧮 Quantity-limited
3. 🔑 Access-limited

⚖️ Ethics: Never fake scarcity; users might get caught once, but never twice.
cards.name: Nudges - Scarcity

cards.desc:
Unexpected things capture our attention... and they can also entice people to take action.

Gaps cause pain.

When we want to know something but can’t, it’s like having an itch that we need to scratch.

To take away the pain, we need to fill the knowledge gap.1
cards.name: Nudges - Curiosity gap

cards.desc:
System 1 - Storing

At the end of every interaction, our brain stores information.

That new information drives the way we Block → Interpret → Act for the following interactions.

And the more loops we go through, the more our brain registers patterns. If the pattern is recognizable and enjoyable, it becomes a habit. What started as slow deliberate decisions is now a fast process.1

Make sure each interaction counts.
cards.name: Storing information: System 1

cards.desc:
Not all features affect customer satisfaction equally.1
Delighters, even roughly executed, bring more satisfaction than well-executed "expected" features.

As delightful features become common, they also become expected. Make sure you never stop innovating!
cards.name: The Kano Model: delighters

cards.desc:
Allow users to disengage from your product with a sense of completion.

In the context of addicting products, it's the ethical thing to do (as you'll see in Mod. 4). And in the context of transactional products like here, it's a way to keep users sane.

If not, people will associate your product to a never-ending treadmill—which may hurt your long-term user retention.1
cards.name: Providing exit points

cards.desc:
This representation of customer journey moments is a digital adaptation of the exhaustive research on what creates memorable experiences.

There are parallels with the New York Times bestselling book by the Heath Brothers "The Power of Moments".

We recommend you read it if you want to create delightful customer journeys.

Peaks & Pits
Jumps & Drops
Transitions
cards.name: Journey moments

cards.desc: Those moments are the highest/lowest absolute psych levels in your experience.
cards.name: Peaks & Pits

cards.desc: These are increases or decreases of psych in your experience.
cards.name: Jumps & drops

cards.desc: These moments mark the start or end of a milestone.
cards.name: Transitions

cards.desc:
Peak-End Rule

Your don’t merely evaluate an experience based on the average or a sum of all the micro-experiences.

That's because the brain doesn't store information like a computer would.

When customers try to remember an experience, their brain reconstructs it.

Specifically, their brain heavily weighs the Peaks, the Pits and the Transitions(start/end).

The good news is that the perception of these shortcuts can be influenced.1



----

Many companies just try to constantly fill the ALL the small pits.

(Let's call 'em "potholes").

That's a mistake… a game of whack-a-mole you'll never win.

----


Instead, you should focus on the 3 Customer Journey Priorities:

1. Fill the biggest Pit.
2. Elevate the main Peak.
3. Mark the Transition.

Ideally, you want to invest the minimum of effort that will cover all three.
cards.name: Peak-End rule

cards.desc:
Imagine you have two options:

A) 🙂 → 😍: You delight your "good" customers, i.e. going from a Net Promoter Score of 8/10 to 10/10.

B) 😐 → 🙂 You satisfy your "average" customers, i.e. going from a Net Promoter Score of 6/10 to 8/10).

Which one do you think is better?

According to research, you’ll earn about 9 times more revenue with the first option than the second option.1
cards.name: The ROI of delight (why invest in the peaks, pits, transitions)

cards.desc:
People prefer smaller, immediate rewards rather than larger, future ones.

In the case of customer journey optimization, it's useful to borrow the financial concept of "actualized value".

In other words: how can your product deliver a smaller reward now (e.g. a preview of something important) instead of having your customers wait… even if it's for a better or more accurate reward later.1
cards.name: Hyperbolic Discounting

cards.desc:
As you saw here, a great way to fill pits and elevate peaks is to re-order or shorten your customer's journey.

This applies to anything, from onboarding to monetization. 

What could be re-ordered in a key part of your product experience to improve the customer experience?
cards.name: Journey Re-ordering

cards.desc:
You have to do your homework and understand what stakeholders really want. Here are 3 key questions that'll establish common ground between you and them:

1) 💛 What's their vision for the future of the business?

2) ☔️ What's the biggest challenge they face right now?

3) 🚧 What's currently stopping them from reaching that vision?

----

...Just like your users, stakeholders have their own hopes, pains & barriers...

----

if you don't agree with them on how to Act.

It probably means they Blocked or Interpreted things differently—
cards.name: Not understanding business goals

cards.desc:
Just like building a good product, relationships take careful research.

Are people not listening?

Maybe it's because you're not working on the right thing (🌵Unrelated.)

Disagree on a solution?

Just like users, your colleagues have desires, pains, and barriers (JTBD). Try to find the underlying problem? What are they not saying?
cards.name: Relationship B.I.A.S

cards.desc:
You've seen how stories are the best way to convey an emotion.

Now, they don't ALWAYS need to be drawn...

Sometimes, starting a conversation with the story of a customer can go a long way—

since you're essentially doing 2 things:

1) Not criticizing someone's work

2) Creating new creative ways of thinking about the same problem (as you've seen with the 6P exercise)

Moving on to the 3rd situation...
cards.name: Not leading with a story

cards.desc:
Use mental models and frameworks and evidence-based insights to shift the conversation to be less about "likes" and "feelings".

Another great way to handle those situations is to: Turn "likes" into "works"

"But why do you think it wouldn't work like that?"
cards.name: Not using the right vocabulary

cards.desc:
Make sure you remove all distractions.

As you saw in the example, it's easy for people to get derailed by details, and unless you want specific feedback on details. 

Try to remove anything that's not related to what you want feedback on.
cards.name: No feedback guardrails

cards.desc:
Great product reviews need preparation:

1. Make sure you remove distractions.
2. Propose more than 1 solution. (to avoid quick roadblocks)
3. Answer the Background Check.

🔎 The Background Check
Before any meeting, answer these 3 questions:
• What problem does it solve?
• How does it affect the user?
• Why is it better than the alternative?

This gives you a chance to make sure there isn't any "hole" in your narrative.
cards.name: Meeting Preparation

cards.desc:
Another way to handle feedback is by:

Leading with a yes - You want to make sure the person knows you listened and understood what they just said and that you're not automatically in defense mode!

In fact, here are the 3 steps to answer any feedback:

###3 steps To Answer feedback

1) Lead with a yes: The first thing you should always do is acknowledge the feedback. Thank them.

2) Repeat & Empathize: Next, briefly summarize what they just said. Re-phrase their response in the form of a question that forces them to talk about it in a way that’s more helpful.

3) Assure: Lastly, assure them you care about the solution, and how you can move forward. 1
cards.name: Not reacting in the right way

cards.desc:
Finding Customer Desires

The best way to frame your product is to deeply understand the subtleties of the Motivation axis of your customers… even better than they do.

We added a worksheet with our favorite questions to help you find opportunities.
cards.name: Motivation levers
StranglerFig - technical approach to replacing old systems

cards.desc:
- People flows (what they do, what we'd like them to do)
- Opportunities
- Break points
- Errors
- Pre-indcident controls
- Post-incident controls
cards.name: Tristan's approach to mapping

cards.desc:
Finding the best path to your desired outcome is commonly known as an 'ill-structured' or 'wicked' problem. There are no right or wrong answers, only better of worse ones.

**Much of the work with these problems is framing the problem itself**

- 'Grow customer accounts' vs 'create customers who want to open more accounts'

^ to pursue business value by creating customer value, we must frame the problem in a customer-centric way - we need to understand the needs, desires and pain points (collectively 'opportunities'* that, if addressed, would drive the business outcome. 

*) The opportunity space represents both the problem & desire spaces

-----

Defining and structuring the opportunity space is how we navigate an ill-structured problem.

However, good teams will try multiple ways of framing the opportunity space. Trying multiple framings to see how they impact the solution space.

This leads to two core tasks for a product team:
- Working out how to map the opportunity space
- Working out how we select which opportunity to pursue
cards.name: The Opportunity Space

cards.desc:
**The Hierarchy**

1. The Root: Your desired outcome: _The business need that reflects how your team can create business value_
2. The Opportunity Space: _The needs, pain-points & desires that if addressed, will drive your desired outcome_
3. The Solution Space (sits below the opportunity space) _where we visually depict the solutions we are exploring_
4. Assumption tests (site below the solution space) _How we'll evaluate which solutions will help us best create customer value in a way that drives business value_

The opportunity space can and should consist of multiple layers of opportunities, i.e. smaller ones that when taken together end up solving larger opportunities. The OST helps teams take large, project size opportunities and break them down. As you work your way vertically down the tree, the opportunities get smaller. Teams can then simply focus on one opportunity at a time. With time, as we address these smaller opportunities, these solutions begin to address the larger opportunities.

------

> “The superior organization of information is a theme that appears over and over again in the study of expert performance.”

Jonassen argues that ill-structured problems are problems that have many solutions. There are no right or wrong answers, only better or worse ones. The solver must start by defining the goal and constraints of the problem before exploring potential solutions.

The short of it is that the problem solver, in our case, the product manager (or even better, the product team), must start by framing the problem.

**Multitracking in a systematic way.**

His first question, “What would you have if you had that?” creates a structure between “I want a house” and “I want to feel grounded in my community.”

His second question, “How else can you feel grounded in your community?”, expands that structure.

----

Let’s use a product example to illustrate this. Imagine you work at Facebook and you are responsible for newsfeed stories.

You might answer the question, “What should we build next?” with an idea, “Let’s add a dislike button.”

Some of us rush off and build that first idea or two. That’s akin to rushing off and buying a house before examining why we want one.

We don’t multitrack in a systematic way.

By jumping straight to solutions, even when we do consider multiple options, we often compare solutions that shouldn’t be compared against each other.

----

Instead, we want to consider which problem each solution solves... and make a decision about which problem is a more valuable opportunity relative to the business goal..... From there, we only compare solutions that deliver on the same opportunities. "Of these solutions, which is most likely to delivery on the target opportunity?"

A systematic approach requires that we consider multiple solutions that deliver on the same opportunity.

Building an opportunity / solution tree, allows us to visualise and externalise our thinking, examine our thinking, and it allows others to critique our thinking. **This can act as our 'roadmap' in many ways** it's flexible enough to not commit us to anything

----

**Steps to building out our Opp / Solution trees**

1) Start with a clear desired outcome

- i.e. start with a Key Result from ORKs
- It's often easier to create separate trees for each goal or metric. 

_For us, it could be: Reach profitability in 6 months, or retain our Conversion to engaged member metric_

2) Gather opportunities that emerge from generative research

- To start, capture what you think the opportunities are in your problem space.  Then quickly refine these with generative research. 

3) Gather solutions, from everywhere, but only solutions that connect to an opportunity

- solutions should only be considered if they help us deliver on one of our target opportunities. If they don’t connect to the tree, they should be considered a distraction.

4) Experiment to evaluate

- Expermints reflect work to test riskiest assumptions behind a solution, not your whole solution. 

---

**A Framework for Continuous Product Discovery**


- The goal isn’t to first discover opportunities and then discover solutions. Instead, we want to be continuously doing both.
- Every week you want to be doing some activities that support discovering and refining new opportunities 
- and every week you want to be doing some activities that support discovering and refining solutions.
- And, of course, every week you want to be delivering value to your customer.

Nobody said dual-track was easy. But it does lead to better products. And isn’t that what we all want?
cards.name: Opportunity / Solution trees

cards.desc:
Instead of asking: "Should we solve this customer need" with OSTs we ask "Which of these customer needs is most important for us to address next?"

Instead of falling in love with our first idea(s), we'll ask: "what else could we build"? or "How else could we address this opportunity"?
cards.name: Compare & Contrast Decisions in place of whether or not decisions

cards.desc:
The best designers do this. As they work on solutions, they learn more about the problem and in learning more about the problem they open up new ways of solving it.

When we learn through testing that a solution won't work, we shouldn't just move onto the next idea. We must pause and consider: "I thought this solution would work, based on my understanding about the customer... it didn't, so what did I misunderstand about the customer?"

We then revise our understanding of the opportunity space before moving onto new solutions. When we do this, our next set of solutions get better.
cards.name: Evolving the problem & solution spaces together

cards.desc:
The shape of our tree can guide our work: The breadth & depth reflects our knowledge of the customer

- One that is too shallow indicates a potential need to do more customer interviews to discover more opportunities
- One that is too sprawling is a reminder to narrow our focus
- If there aren't many solutions identified for the target opportunity, we can hold an ideation session.
- If we don't have enough assumption tests in flight this can prompt us to ramp up testing

Top down & bottom-up.

Many teams work from the top - identifying a desired outcome, mapping the opportunities, then solutions, then assumption tests. However great teams can also work bottom up: **using assumption tests to evaluate solutions and evolve the opportunity space**. In evaluating the opportunity space, understanding how they might best reach that outcome, and how to measure that outcome  will evolve. 

They interview week over week, continuously revising the tree, even after selecting a target opportunity. They consider multiple solutions to the target opportunity, setting up good compare and contrast decisions. They run assumption tests in parallel across the solution set, so they don't over-commit to less than optimal solutions
cards.name: Tending to an Opportunity / Solution tree (the arborist) ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

cards.desc: See pages 39-40
cards.name: Sharing with stakeholders and bringing them on the journey effectively

cards.desc:
Business outcomes are typically financial measures, but can also represent strategic initiatives (i.e. grow market share in Asia, increase sales to this customer segment). They are however almost always lagging indicators.

Product metrics sit squarely within the product team's sphere of control. We assign product metrics to product teams for accountability, responsibility and ownership, as they have direct control over it. Whereas a broader business goal, they only have some control over.

Traction metrics are not appropriate to assign to a product team as they tend to focus on the output of a specific solution. In cases however, where you have a mature product and a very confident understanding that that traction metric is crucial, it can be appropriate to optimise for it specifically.
cards.name: Business vs Product vs Traction metrics

cards.desc:
When faced with a new outcome to achieve, the evidence suggests that first rallying around a 'learning' goal is more appropriate than a 'performance' goal.

Learning: "Discover the opportunities that will drive engagement"
Performance: "Increase engagement by 10%"

We often need to do discovery to understand how best to measure a product outcome. I.e. learn what leads to churn first and use that knowledge to refine your target metric over time.
cards.name: The case for 'learning goals'

cards.desc:
Experience maps are a great starting point to document current knowledge. They should first be completed individually by the product trio and then combined into a more holistic view of the current state of knowledge. Starting individually is important as it helps prevent group think by giving each member an opportunity to develop their own perspective.

This is treated only as a series of hunches and possibilities, not the truth, but it gives a clear starting point. You make explicit what you think you know, where there are open questions, and what needs vetting in upcoming interviews with customers.

This artefact helps you explore your own, and your team-mates' perspectives and it guides customer interviews. It helps give structure to the opportunity space and is refined week on week as you learn more.

---

**Setting the scope of an experience map**

This is an important first step. The scope should be in relation to the outcome you're looking for. If you're focused on a traction metric, due to having high confidence about a specific area / opportunity, then you might set the scope quite narrow - understand how users entertain themselves with our service.

In most cases however, you'll want a scope that gives you room to explore, whilst also staying focused on your desired outcome. I.e. "how do customers entertain themselves with video"....

A vend example could be: "What's preventing retail store owners from keeping their online store current & up-to-date?"

---

**Experience maps can start as a 6P story**

- It focuses on the story around the interactions with the product, not the product itself. It draws the experiences of the customer.

**But they develop into more detailed and specific maps as we learn**

- As we learn more about customer, we'll add a lot more detail to the map - i.e. the various different ways they can hear about our product, the various other products they interact with on the way to solving their problem, etc.

---

**Combining individual maps into a collective with nodes and links**

**Nodes**: Actions or points in time in the experience
**Links**: What connect the nodes together

1. Arrange all nodes from individual maps into one collective map
2. Collapse similar / duplicate nodes together (careful not to over-generalise to lose important detail / context)
3. Determine the links between each node. The good, the bad, those that loop back, where people give up, etc. Motivation + Ability mapping framework might play nicely here
4. Add context to each step: Thinking, feeling, doing.
cards.name: A starting point: Visualising what you know with an Experience Map

cards.desc:
JTBD talks about understanding higher level aspirations and mapping product experiences to this. However, what about when aspirations don't actually reflect what the customer does day to day.

I might say I have an aspiration to live sustainably. but what if I always choose the cheapest products? What lies behind this?

When understanding aspirations therefore, it must be cross-referenced with an understanding of what the customer _actually does_ or at least _tries to do_.

YG was a good example, people told us all the ways they went out of their way to achieve their aspirations. It was validation that went beyond aspiration and showed they had invested skin in the game.

-----

Theresa Torres example: Recruiters wanted to hire 'passive candidates'... but they almost always hired 'active candidates'... why? because their incentives were such that they benefited from filling roles fast.
cards.name: A caveat to JTBD aspirations - reality vs aspirations

cards.desc:
RQs: What we are trying to learn
IQs: What we ask

When interviewing, you'll want to balance breadth in uncovering opportunities - those pain points, desires that matter most to the customer you're interviewing... whilst leaving space to dive deep into the opportunity you're focused on.

However, don't want to spend time investigating an opportunity the customer doesn't care about, so sometimes this won't align.

**The primary Research Question in any interview should be - what pain points, needs, desires matter most to this customer**

^ Once you've uncovered these, you'll want to dive deep into the specifics of any of those opportunities. You want the customer to set the direction of the interview in terms of what you dive into, even though you might have specific opportunities in mind. **What matters most to your customer trumps what you need to learn**

-------

As per timeline interviewing, focus on recent actual behaviour that the customer can effectively recall and talk to. We develop story questions to elicit this knowledge... the scope of the story you want to elicit will change throughout the discovery process, i.e.:

####Narrow - for optimising your existing product

- **Tell us about the last time you used our streaming service**: Elicit pain points, needs, desires with your product

vs

####Broader - to uncover new opportunities

- **Tell us about the last time you watched any streaming service**: Elicit opportunities around your product and also competitors


vs

####Broadest - might help you uncover new markets
